**Bucharest** ( [UK](/wiki/British_English "British English"): [/ˌbuːkəˈrɛst/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/0/07/LL-Q1860_%28eng%29-Vealhurl-Bucharest.wav/LL-Q1860_%28eng%29-Vealhurl-Bucharest.wav.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:LL-Q1860_(eng)-Vealhurl-Bucharest.wav "File:LL-Q1860 (eng)-Vealhurl-Bucharest.wav")^ [*BOO-kə-REST*](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key"), [US](/wiki/American_English "American English"): [/ˈbuːkərɛst/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [*-⁠rest*](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key"); [Romanian](/wiki/Romanian_language "Romanian language"): *București* [\[bukuˈreʃtʲ\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Romanian "Help:IPA/Romanian") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/71/Ro-Bucure%C8%99ti.ogg/Ro-Bucure%C8%99ti.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:Ro-Bucure%C8%99ti.ogg "File:Ro-București.ogg")^) is the capital and largest city of [Romania](/wiki/Romania "Romania"). The metropolis stands on the River [Dâmbovița](/wiki/D%C3%A2mbovi%C8%9Ba_(river) "Dâmbovița (river)") in south-eastern Romania. Its population is officially estimated at 1.76 million residents within a greater [metropolitan area](/wiki/Bucharest_metropolitan_area "Bucharest metropolitan area") of 2.3 million residents, which makes Bucharest the [8th most-populous city](/wiki/List_of_cities_in_the_European_Union_by_population_within_city_limits "List of cities in the European Union by population within city limits") in the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union"). The city area measures 240 km^2^ (93 sq mi) and comprises 6 districts (*[Sectoare](/wiki/Sectors_of_Bucharest "Sectors of Bucharest")* ), while the metropolitan area covers 1,811 km^2^ (699 sq mi). Bucharest is a major cultural, political and economic hub, and the country's seat of government.{#ooui-php-2}

Bucharest was first mentioned in documents in 1459. The city became the capital in 1862 and is the centre of Romanian media, culture, and art. Its architecture is a mix of historical (mostly [Eclectic](/wiki/History_of_architecture#Revivalism_and_Eclecticism "History of architecture"), but also [Neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture "Neoclassical architecture") and [Art Nouveau](/wiki/Art_Nouveau_architecture "Art Nouveau architecture")), [interbellum](/wiki/Interbellum "Interbellum") ([Bauhaus](/wiki/Bauhaus "Bauhaus"), [Art Deco](/wiki/Art_Deco "Art Deco"), and [Romanian Revival architecture](/wiki/Romanian_Revival_architecture "Romanian Revival architecture")), [socialist era](/wiki/Socialist_realism "Socialist realism"), and [modern](/wiki/Modern_architecture "Modern architecture"). In the period between the two World Wars, the city's elegant architecture and the sophistication of its elite earned Bucharest the nicknames of Little Paris or [Paris of the East](/wiki/Paris_of_the_East_(disambiguation) "Paris of the East (disambiguation)").^[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)^ Although buildings and districts in the historic city centre were heavily damaged or destroyed by war, earthquakes, and even [Nicolae Ceaușescu](/wiki/Nicolae_Ceau%C8%99escu "Nicolae Ceaușescu")'s program of [systematization](/wiki/Systematization_(Romania) "Systematization (Romania)"), many survived and have been renovated. In recent years, the city has been experiencing an economic and cultural boom.^[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)^^[\[8\]](#cite_note-8)^ It is one of the fastest-growing high-tech cities in Europe.^[\[9\]](#cite_note-9)^^[\[10\]](#cite_note-10)^^[\[11\]](#cite_note-11)^^[\[12\]](#cite_note-12)^^[\[13\]](#cite_note-13)^ In 2016, the historical city centre was listed as 'endangered' by the [World Monuments Watch](/wiki/World_Monuments_Watch "World Monuments Watch").^[\[14\]](#cite_note-wmf.org-14)^{#cite_ref-wmf.org_14-0}

In January 2023, there were 1.74 million inhabitants living within the city limits,^[\[2\]](#cite_note-Population.Bucharest-2)^ and adding the satellite towns around the [urban area](/wiki/List_of_urban_areas_of_the_European_Union "List of urban areas of the European Union"), the proposed [metropolitan area](/wiki/Bucharest_metropolitan_area "Bucharest metropolitan area") of Bucharest would have a population of 2.3 million people.^[\[2\]](#cite_note-Population.Bucharest-2)^ In 2020, the government used 2.5 million people as the basis for pandemic reports.^[\[15\]](#cite_note-15)^ Bucharest is the [eighth largest city](/wiki/List_of_cities_in_the_European_Union_by_population_within_city_limits "List of cities in the European Union by population within city limits") in the European Union by population within city limits. In 2017, Bucharest was the European city with the highest growth of tourists who stay over night, according to the [Mastercard](/wiki/Mastercard "Mastercard") Global Index of Urban Destinations.^[\[16\]](#cite_note-16)^ As for the past two consecutive years, 2018 and 2019, Bucharest ranked as the European destination with the highest potential for development according to the same study.^[\[17\]](#cite_note-17)^{#cite_ref-17}

Economically, Bucharest is the most prosperous city in Romania and the richest capital and city in the region, having surpassed Budapest since 2017.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-18)^^[\[19\]](#cite_note-19)^^[\[20\]](#cite_note-20)^ The city has a number of large convention facilities, educational institutes, cultural venues, traditional 'shopping arcades' and recreational areas. The city proper is administratively known as the 'Municipality of Bucharest' ([Romanian](/wiki/Romanian_language "Romanian language"): *Municipiul București* ), and has the same administrative level as that of a national [county](/wiki/Counties_of_Romania "Counties of Romania"), being further subdivided into six [sectors](/wiki/Sectors_of_Bucharest "Sectors of Bucharest"), each governed by a local mayor.{#cite_ref-20}  

Etymology {#Etymology}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Etymology")\]

The Romanian name *București* has an unverified origin. Tradition connects the founding of Bucharest with the name of *[Bucur](/wiki/Bucur_(legendary_shepherd) "Bucur (legendary shepherd)")* , who was a prince, an outlaw, a fisherman, a shepherd or a hunter, according to different legends. In [Romanian](/wiki/Romanian_language "Romanian language"), the word stem *bucurie* means 'joy' ('happiness'),^[\[21\]](#cite_note-21)^ hence the city Bucharest means 'city of joy'.^[\[22\]](#cite_note-22)^{#cite_ref-22}

Other etymologies are given by early scholars, including the one of an [Ottoman](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") traveller, [Evliya Çelebi](/wiki/Evliya_%C3%87elebi "Evliya Çelebi"), who claimed that Bucharest was named after a certain 'Abu-Kariș', from the tribe of '[Bani-Kureiș](/wiki/Banu_Quraysh "Banu Quraysh")'. In 1781, [Austrian](/wiki/Austrians "Austrians") historian Franz Sulzer claimed that it was related to *bucurie* (joy), *bucuros* (joyful), or *a se bucura* (to be joyful), while an early 19th-century book published in [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna") assumed its name to be derived from 'Bukovie', a [beech](/wiki/Beech "Beech") forest.^[\[23\]](#cite_note-Georgescu77-23)^ In [English](/wiki/English_language "English language"), the city's name was formerly rendered as *Bukarest* . A native or resident of Bucharest is called a 'Bucharester' (Romanian: *bucureștean*).{#cite_ref-Georgescu77_23-0}  

History {#History}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: History")\]  
Main article: [History of Bucharest](/wiki/History_of_Bucharest "History of Bucharest")  
For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of Bucharest](/wiki/Timeline_of_Bucharest "Timeline of Bucharest").
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Nicolae_Ionescu_-_Victory_Avenue_in_1923%2C_Sunday_at_noon.jpg/220px-Nicolae_Ionescu_-_Victory_Avenue_in_1923%2C_Sunday_at_noon.jpg)](/wiki/File:Nicolae_Ionescu_-_Victory_Avenue_in_1923,_Sunday_at_noon.jpg) Bucharest in 1923 during Romania's golden age, the interwar period [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Hotel_Continental_-_Calea_Victoriei.jpg/220px-Hotel_Continental_-_Calea_Victoriei.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hotel_Continental_-_Calea_Victoriei.jpg) Often compared to the [Champs-Élysées](/wiki/Champs-%C3%89lys%C3%A9es "Champs-Élysées"), the current [Calea Victoriei](/wiki/Calea_Victoriei "Calea Victoriei") becomes a [pedestrian zone](/wiki/Pedestrian_zone "Pedestrian zone") on the weekend.

Bucharest's history alternated periods of development and decline from the early settlements in [antiquity](/wiki/Classical_antiquity "Classical antiquity") until its consolidation as the national capital of [Romania](/wiki/Romania "Romania") late in the 19th century. First mentioned as the '[Citadel](/wiki/Citadel "Citadel") of București' in 1459, it became the residence of the ruler of Wallachia, Voivode [Vlad the Impaler](/wiki/Vlad_the_Impaler "Vlad the Impaler").^[\[24\]](#cite_note-Giurescu-24)^^: 23^{#cite_ref-Giurescu_24-0}

The [Old Princely Court](/wiki/Curtea_Veche "Curtea Veche") (*Curtea Veche* ) was erected by [Mircea Ciobanul](/wiki/Mircea_Ciobanul "Mircea Ciobanul") in the mid-16th century. Under subsequent rulers, Bucharest was established as the summer residence of the royal court. During the years to come, it competed with [Târgoviște](/wiki/T%C3%A2rgovi%C8%99te "Târgoviște") on the status of capital city after an increase in the importance of Southern [Muntenia](/wiki/Muntenia "Muntenia") brought about by the demands of the [*suzerain*](/wiki/Suzerainty "Suzerainty") power -- the [Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire").

Bucharest finally became the permanent location of the Wallachian court after 1698 (starting with the reign of [Constantin Brâncoveanu](/wiki/Constantin_Br%C3%A2ncoveanu "Constantin Brâncoveanu")). The city was partly destroyed by natural disasters and rebuilt several times during the following 200 years.

The Ottomans appointed Greek administrators ([Phanariotes](/wiki/Phanariotes "Phanariotes")) to run the town ([Ottoman Turkish](/wiki/Ottoman_Turkish_language "Ottoman Turkish language"): بكرش, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Ottoman_Turkish "Romanization of Ottoman Turkish"): *Bukreş*^[\[25\]](#cite_note-25)^) from the 18th century. The [1821 Wallachian uprising](/wiki/Wallachian_uprising_of_1821 "Wallachian uprising of 1821") initiated by [Tudor Vladimirescu](/wiki/Tudor_Vladimirescu "Tudor Vladimirescu") led to the end of the rule of Constantinople Greeks in Bucharest.^[\[26\]](#cite_note-26)^{#cite_ref-26}

In 1813--14 the city was hit by [Caragea's plague](/wiki/Caragea%27s_plague "Caragea's plague"). The city was wrested from Ottoman influence and occupied at several intervals by the [Habsburg monarchy](/wiki/Habsburg_monarchy "Habsburg monarchy") (1716, 1737, 1789) and [Imperial Russia](/wiki/Imperial_Russia "Imperial Russia") (three times between 1768 and 1806). It was placed under [Russian administration](/wiki/Regulamentul_Organic "Regulamentul Organic") between 1828 and the [Crimean War](/wiki/Crimean_War "Crimean War"), with an interlude during the Bucharest-centred [1848 Wallachian revolution](/wiki/1848_Wallachian_revolution "1848 Wallachian revolution"). Later, an [Austrian](/wiki/Austrian_Empire "Austrian Empire") garrison took possession after the Russian departure (remaining in the city until March 1857). On 23 March 1847, a fire consumed about 2,000 buildings, destroying a third of the city.

In 1862, after [Wallachia](/wiki/Wallachia "Wallachia") and [Moldavia](/wiki/Moldavia "Moldavia") were united to form the [Principality of Romania](/wiki/United_Principalities "United Principalities"), Bucharest became the new nation's capital city. In 1881, it became the political centre of the newly proclaimed [Kingdom of Romania](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Romania "Kingdom of Romania") under King [Carol I](/wiki/Carol_I_of_Romania "Carol I of Romania"). During the second half of the 19th century, the city's population increased dramatically, and a new period of urban development began. During this period, [gas lighting](/wiki/Gas_lighting "Gas lighting"), [horse-drawn trams](/wiki/Horsecar "Horsecar"), and limited [electrification](/wiki/Electrification "Electrification") were introduced.^[\[27\]](#cite_note-27)^ The Dâmbovița River was also massively channelled in 1883, thus putting a stop to previously endemic floods like the [1865 flooding of Bucharest](/wiki/1865_flooding_of_Bucharest "1865 flooding of Bucharest").^[\[28\]](#cite_note-28)^ The [Fortifications of Bucharest](/wiki/Fortifications_of_Bucharest "Fortifications of Bucharest") were built. The extravagant architecture and cosmopolitan high culture of this period won Bucharest the nickname of 'Paris of the East' (*Parisul Estului* ), with the [Calea Victoriei](/wiki/Calea_Victoriei "Calea Victoriei") as its [Champs-Élysées](/wiki/Champs-%C3%89lys%C3%A9es "Champs-Élysées").{#cite_ref-28}

Between 6 December 1916 and November 1918, the city was occupied by [German](/wiki/German_Empire "German Empire") forces as a result of the [Battle of Bucharest](/wiki/Battle_of_Bucharest "Battle of Bucharest"), with the official capital temporarily moved to [Iași](/wiki/Ia%C8%99i "Iași") (also called Jassy), in the Moldavia region. After World War I, Bucharest became the capital of [Greater Romania](/wiki/Greater_Romania "Greater Romania"). In the interwar years, Bucharest's urban development continued, with the city gaining an average of 30,000 new residents each year. Also, some of the city's main landmarks were built in this period, including [Arcul de Triumf](/wiki/Arcul_de_Triumf "Arcul de Triumf") and [Palatul Telefoanelor](/wiki/Palatul_Telefoanelor "Palatul Telefoanelor").^[\[29\]](#cite_note-29)^ However, the [Great Depression in Romania](/wiki/Great_Depression_in_Romania "Great Depression in Romania") took its toll on Bucharest's citizens, culminating in the [Grivița Strike of 1933](/wiki/Grivi%C8%9Ba_Strike_of_1933 "Grivița Strike of 1933").^[\[30\]](#cite_note-30)^{#cite_ref-30}

In January 1941, the city was the scene of the [Legionnaires' rebellion and Bucharest pogrom](/wiki/Legionnaires%27_rebellion_and_Bucharest_pogrom "Legionnaires' rebellion and Bucharest pogrom"). As the capital of an [Axis](/wiki/Axis_Powers "Axis Powers") country and a major transit point for Axis troops en route to the [Eastern Front](/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_II) "Eastern Front (World War II)"), Bucharest suffered heavy damage during World War II due to [Allied bombings](/wiki/Bombing_of_Bucharest_in_World_War_II "Bombing of Bucharest in World War II"). On 23 August 1944, Bucharest was the site of [the royal coup](/wiki/Romania_during_World_War_II#The_royal_coup "Romania during World War II") which brought Romania into the [Allied](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of World War II") camp. The city suffered a short period of Nazi [Luftwaffe](/wiki/Luftwaffe "Luftwaffe") bombings, as well as a failed attempt by German troops to regain the city.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Curtea_Veche_1.jpg/220px-Curtea_Veche_1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Curtea_Veche_1.jpg) The [Old Princely Court](/wiki/Curtea_Veche "Curtea Veche") (*Curtea Veche* ), the former residence of ruler [Vlad the Impaler](/wiki/Vlad_the_Impaler "Vlad the Impaler"), is located in the [Old Town](/wiki/Bucharest_Old_Town "Bucharest Old Town").

After the establishment of [communism in Romania](/wiki/Communist_Romania "Communist Romania"), the city continued growing. New districts were constructed, most of them dominated by [tower blocks](/wiki/Tower_block "Tower block"). During [Nicolae Ceaușescu](/wiki/Nicolae_Ceau%C8%99escu "Nicolae Ceaușescu")'s leadership (1965--89), a part of the historic city [was demolished](/wiki/Ceau%C8%99ima "Ceaușima") and replaced by '[Socialist realism](/wiki/Socialist_realism "Socialist realism")' style development: (1) the [Centrul Civic](/wiki/Centrul_Civic "Centrul Civic") (the Civic Centre) and (2) the [Palace of the Parliament](/wiki/Palace_of_the_Parliament "Palace of the Parliament"), for which an entire historic quarter was razed to make way for Ceaușescu's megalomaniac plans. On 4 March 1977, an [earthquake centred in Vrancea](/wiki/1977_Vrancea_earthquake "1977 Vrancea earthquake"), about 135 km (83.89 mi) away, claimed 1,500 lives and caused further damage to the historic centre.

The [Romanian Revolution of 1989](/wiki/Romanian_Revolution_of_1989 "Romanian Revolution of 1989") began with massive anti-Ceaușescu protests in [Timișoara](/wiki/Timi%C8%99oara "Timișoara") in December 1989 and continued in Bucharest, leading to the overthrow of the [Communist regime](/wiki/Communist_Romania "Communist Romania"). Dissatisfied with the postrevolutionary leadership of the [National Salvation Front](/wiki/National_Salvation_Front_(Romania) "National Salvation Front (Romania)"), some student leagues and opposition groups organised anti-Communist rallies in early 1990, which caused the political change.

Since 2000, the city has been continuously modernised. Residential and commercial developments are underway, particularly in the northern districts; Bucharest's old historic centre has undergone restoration since the mid-2000s.^[\[31\]](#cite_note-31)^{#cite_ref-31}

In 2015, 64 people were killed in the [Colectiv nightclub fire](/wiki/Colectiv_nightclub_fire "Colectiv nightclub fire"). Later the Romanian capital saw the [2017--2019 Romanian protests](/wiki/2017%E2%80%932019_Romanian_protests "2017–2019 Romanian protests") against the judicial reforms,^[\[32\]](#cite_note-32)^ with a 2018 protest ending with 450 people injured.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-33)^{#cite_ref-33}  

### Treaties {#Treaties}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Treaties")\]

The following treaties were signed in the city:

* [Treaty of Bucharest (1812)](/wiki/Treaty_of_Bucharest_(1812) "Treaty of Bucharest (1812)"), between the Ottoman Empire and the Russian Empire ending the [Russo-Turkish War (1806--1812)](/wiki/Russo-Turkish_War_(1806%E2%80%931812) "Russo-Turkish War (1806–1812)")
* [Treaty of Bucharest (1886)](/wiki/Treaty_of_Bucharest_(1886) "Treaty of Bucharest (1886)"), between Serbia and Bulgaria ending the [Serbian--Bulgarian War](/wiki/Serbo-Bulgarian_War "Serbo-Bulgarian War")
* [Treaty of Bucharest (1913)](/wiki/Treaty_of_Bucharest_(1913) "Treaty of Bucharest (1913)"), between Bulgaria, Romania, Serbia, Montenegro and Greece ending of the [Second Balkan War](/wiki/Second_Balkan_War "Second Balkan War")
* [Treaty of Bucharest (1916)](/wiki/Treaty_of_Bucharest_(1916) "Treaty of Bucharest (1916)"), a treaty of alliance between Romania and the [Entente Powers](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I "Allies of World War I")
* [Treaty of Bucharest (1918)](/wiki/Treaty_of_Bucharest_(1918) "Treaty of Bucharest (1918)"), between Romania and the [Central Powers](/wiki/Central_Powers "Central Powers")

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Geography")\]  

### General {#General}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: General")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Bucuresti_de_sus.jpg/220px-Bucuresti_de_sus.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bucuresti_de_sus.jpg) Bucharest is [Romania](/wiki/Romania "Romania")'s capital and largest city.

The city is situated on the banks of the [Dâmbovița River](/wiki/D%C3%A2mbovi%C8%9Ba_River "Dâmbovița River"), which flows into the Argeș River, a tributary of the Danube. [Several lakes](/wiki/List_of_lakes_in_Bucharest "List of lakes in Bucharest") -- the most important of which are Lake Herăstrău, Lake Floreasca, Lake Tei, and Lake Colentina -- stretch across the northern parts of the city, along the [Colentina River](/wiki/Colentina_(river) "Colentina (river)"), a tributary of the Dâmbovița. In addition, in the centre of the capital is a small artificial lake -- Lake Cișmigiu -- surrounded by the [Cișmigiu Gardens](/wiki/Ci%C8%99migiu_Gardens "Cișmigiu Gardens"). These gardens have a rich history, having been frequented by poets and writers. Opened in 1847 and based on the plans of German architect Carl F.W. Meyer, the gardens are the main recreational facility in the city centre.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Parcul_Herastrau_park_lake_Bucharest_Bucuresti_Romania_2.JPG/220px-Parcul_Herastrau_park_lake_Bucharest_Bucuresti_Romania_2.JPG)](/wiki/File:Parcul_Herastrau_park_lake_Bucharest_Bucuresti_Romania_2.JPG) [King Michael I Park](/wiki/King_Michael_I_Park "King Michael I Park") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Lacul_Vacaresti_-_Delta_Vacaresti_-_Vara.jpg/220px-Lacul_Vacaresti_-_Delta_Vacaresti_-_Vara.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lacul_Vacaresti_-_Delta_Vacaresti_-_Vara.jpg) [Văcărești Nature Park](/wiki/V%C4%83c%C4%83re%C8%99ti_Nature_Park "Văcărești Nature Park") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Parcul_Carol_-_toamna.jpg/220px-Parcul_Carol_-_toamna.jpg)](/wiki/File:Parcul_Carol_-_toamna.jpg) [Carol Park](/wiki/Carol_Park "Carol Park") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/2017_Cismigiu%2C_Bucuresti_%283%29.jpg/220px-2017_Cismigiu%2C_Bucuresti_%283%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:2017_Cismigiu,_Bucuresti_(3).jpg) [Cișmigiu Gardens](/wiki/Ci%C8%99migiu_Gardens "Cișmigiu Gardens") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Tineretului_lake.jpg/220px-Tineretului_lake.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tineretului_lake.jpg) [Tineretului Park](/wiki/Tineretului_Park "Tineretului Park") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/2018_Parcul_IOR_Mai.jpg/220px-2018_Parcul_IOR_Mai.jpg)](/wiki/File:2018_Parcul_IOR_Mai.jpg) Alexandru Ioan Cuza Park (also known as IOR Park or Titan Park)

Bucharest parks and gardens also include [Herăstrău Park](/wiki/King_Michael_I_Park "King Michael I Park"), [Tineretului Park](/wiki/Tineretului_Park "Tineretului Park") and the [Botanical Garden](/wiki/Botanical_Garden_of_Bucharest "Botanical Garden of Bucharest"). Herăstrău Park is located in the northern part of the city, around Lake Herăstrău, and includes the site the [Village Museum](/wiki/Dimitrie_Gusti_National_Village_Museum "Dimitrie Gusti National Village Museum"). [Grigore Antipa Museum](/wiki/Grigore_Antipa_National_Museum_of_Natural_History "Grigore Antipa National Museum of Natural History") is also near in the Victoriei Square. One of its best known locations are [Hard Rock Cafe](/wiki/Hard_Rock_Cafe "Hard Rock Cafe") Bucharest and [Berăria H](/wiki/Ber%C4%83ria_H "Berăria H") (one of the largest beer halls in Europe). Tineretului Park was created in 1965 and designed as the main recreational space for southern Bucharest. It contains a Mini Town which is a play area for kids. The Botanical Garden, located in the [Cotroceni](/wiki/Cotroceni "Cotroceni") neighbourhood a bit west of the city centre, is the largest of its kind in Romania and contains over 10,000 species of plants (many of them exotic); it originated as the pleasure park of the royal family.^[\[34\]](#cite_note-34)^ Besides them, there are many other smaller parks that should be visited, some of them being still large. Alexandru Ioan Cuza Park, Kiseleff Park, [Carol Park](/wiki/Carol_Park "Carol Park"), Izvor Park, [Grădina Icoanei](/wiki/Gr%C4%83dina_Icoanei "Grădina Icoanei"), Circului Park and Moghioroș Park are a few of them. Other large parks in Bucharest are: National Park, Tei Park, Eroilor Park and Crângași Park with [Morii Lake](/wiki/Lacul_Morii "Lacul Morii").{#cite_ref-34}

[Lake Văcărești](/wiki/Lake_V%C4%83c%C4%83re%C8%99ti "Lake Văcărești") is located in the southern part of the city. Over 190 hectares, including 90 hectares of water, host 97 species of birds, half of them protected by law, and at least seven species of mammals.^[\[35\]](#cite_note-35)^ The lake is surrounded by buildings of flats and is an odd result of human intervention and nature taking its course. The area was a small village that Ceaușescu attempted to convert into a lake. After demolishing the houses and building the concrete basin, the plan was abandoned following the 1989 revolution.^[\[36\]](#cite_note-36)^ For nearly two decades, the area shifted from being an abandoned green space where children could play and sunbathe, to being contested by previous owners of the land there, to being closed for redevelopment into a sports centre. The redevelopment deal failed,^[\[37\]](#cite_note-37)^ and over the following years, the green space grew into a unique habitat. In May 2016, the lake was declared a national park, the [Văcărești Nature Park](/wiki/V%C4%83c%C4%83re%C8%99ti_Nature_Park "Văcărești Nature Park").^[\[38\]](#cite_note-38)^ Dubbed the 'Delta of Bucharest', the area is protected.^[\[39\]](#cite_note-39)^{#cite_ref-39}

Bucharest is situated in the center of the Romanian Plain, in an area once covered by the Vlăsiei Forest, which after it was cleared, gave way for a fertile flatland. As with many cities, Bucharest is traditionally considered to be built upon seven hills, similar to the seven hills of Rome. Bucharest's seven hills are: Mihai Vodă, [Dealul Mitropoliei](/wiki/Dealul_Mitropoliei "Dealul Mitropoliei"), Radu Vodă, [Cotroceni](/wiki/Cotroceni "Cotroceni"), [Dealul Spirii](/wiki/Dealul_Spirii "Dealul Spirii"), [Văcărești](/wiki/V%C4%83c%C4%83re%C8%99ti,_Bucharest "Văcărești, Bucharest"), and Sfântu Gheorghe Nou.

The city has an area of 226 km^2^ (87 sq mi). The altitude varies from 55.8 m (183.1 ft) at the Dâmbovița bridge in Cățelu, southeastern Bucharest and 91.5 m (300.2 ft) at the [Militari](/wiki/Militari "Militari") church. The city has a roughly round shape, with the centre situated in the cross-way of the main north--south/east-west axes at [University Square](/wiki/University_Square,_Bucharest "University Square, Bucharest"). The milestone for Romania's [Kilometre Zero](/wiki/Kilometre_Zero_(Bucharest) "Kilometre Zero (Bucharest)") is placed just south of University Square in front of the New St. George Church (Sfântul Gheorghe Nou) at St. George Square (Piața Sfântul Gheorghe). Bucharest's radius, from University Square to the city limits in all directions, varies from 10 to 12 km (6 to 7 mi).

Until recently, the regions surrounding Bucharest were largely rural, but after 1989, suburbs started to be built around Bucharest, in the surrounding [Ilfov County](/wiki/Ilfov_County "Ilfov County"). This [county](/wiki/Counties_of_Romania "Counties of Romania"), which has experienced rapid demographic growth in the 21st century, being the fastest growing Romanian county between 2011 and 2021, had a population of 542,686 people at the [2021 Romanian census](/wiki/2021_Romanian_census "2021 Romanian census").^[\[40\]](#cite_note-40)^ In the 21st century, many of Ilfov county's villages and communes developed into high-income [commuter towns](/wiki/Commuter_town "Commuter town"), which act like suburbs or satellites of Bucharest.{#cite_ref-40}  

Climate {#Climate}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Climate")\]

Bucharest has a [humid continental climate](/wiki/Humid_continental_climate "Humid continental climate") (*Dfa* by the 0 °C isotherm), or a [humid subtropical climate](/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate "Humid subtropical climate") ([Köppen](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"): *Cfa* by the -3 °C isotherm), with hot, humid summers and cold, snowy winters. Owing to its position on the Romanian Plain, the city's winters can get windy, though some of the winds are mitigated due to urbanisation. Winter temperatures often dip below 0 °C (32 °F), sometimes even to −10 °C (14 °F). In summer, the average high temperature is 29.8 °C (85.6 °F) (the average for July and August). Temperatures frequently reach 35 to 40 °C (95 to 104 °F) in midsummer in the city centre. Although average [precipitation](/wiki/Precipitation_(meteorology) "Precipitation (meteorology)") in summer is moderate, occasional heavy storms occur. During spring and autumn, daytime temperatures vary between 17 and 22 °C (63 and 72 °F), and precipitation during spring tends to be higher than in summer, with more frequent yet milder periods of rain.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-41)^^[\[42\]](#cite_note-42)^{#cite_ref-42}

Government {#Government}
------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Government")\]  

### Administration {#Administration}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Administration")\]  
See also: [Bucharest metropolitan area](/wiki/Bucharest_metropolitan_area "Bucharest metropolitan area")

Bucharest has a unique status in Romanian administration, since it is the only municipal area that is not part of a [county](/wiki/Counties_of_Romania "Counties of Romania"). Its population, however, is larger than that of any other [Romanian county](/wiki/List_of_Romanian_counties_by_population "List of Romanian counties by population"), hence the power of the Bucharest General Municipality (*Primăria Generală*), which is the capital's local government body, is the same as any other Romanian county council.

The Municipality of Bucharest, along with the surrounding Ilfov County, is part of the București -- Ilfov development region project, which is equivalent to [NUTS-II](/wiki/NUTS-II "NUTS-II") regions in the European Union and is used both by the EU and the Romanian government for statistical analysis, and to co-ordinate regional development projects and manage funds from the EU. The Bucharest-Ilfov development region is not, however, an administrative entity yet.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Bucure%C5%9Fti_sectoare.svg/220px-Bucure%C5%9Fti_sectoare.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Bucure%C5%9Fti_sectoare.svg) [Sectors of Bucharest](/wiki/Sectors_of_Bucharest "Sectors of Bucharest")

The city government is headed by a [general mayor](/wiki/Mayor_of_Bucharest "Mayor of Bucharest") (*Primar General* ). Since 29 October 2020 onwards, it is [Nicușor Dan](/wiki/Nicu%C8%99or_Dan "Nicușor Dan"), currently an independent politician previously backed by the [PNL](/wiki/National_Liberal_Party_(Romania) "National Liberal Party (Romania)")-[USR PLUS](/wiki/2020_USR-PLUS_Alliance "2020 USR-PLUS Alliance") centre-right alliance at the [2020 Romanian local elections](/wiki/2020_Romanian_local_elections "2020 Romanian local elections"). Decisions are approved and discussed by the capital's [General Council](/wiki/General_Council_of_Bucharest "General Council of Bucharest") (*Consiliu General* ) made up of 55 elected councilors. Furthermore, the city is divided into six administrative [sectors](/wiki/Sectors_of_Bucharest "Sectors of Bucharest") (*sectoare*), each of which has its own 27-seat sectoral council, town hall, and mayor. The powers of the local government over a certain area are, therefore, shared both by the Bucharest municipality and the local sectoral councils with little or no overlapping of authority. The general rule is that the main capital municipality is responsible for citywide utilities such as the water and sewage system, the overall transport system, and the main boulevards, while sectoral town halls manage the contact between individuals and the local government, secondary streets and parks maintenance, schools administration, and cleaning services.

The six sectors are numbered from one to six and are disposed radially so that each one has under its administration a certain area of the city centre. They are numbered clockwise and are further divided into sectoral quarters (*cartiere*) which are not part of the official administrative division:

* **[Sector 1](/wiki/Sector_1_(Bucharest) "Sector 1 (Bucharest)")** (population 227,717): [Dorobanți](/wiki/Doroban%C8%9Bi "Dorobanți"), [Băneasa](/wiki/B%C4%83neasa "Băneasa"), [Aviației](/wiki/Avia%C8%9Biei "Aviației"), [Pipera](/wiki/Pipera "Pipera"), Aviatorilor, Primăverii, Romană, Victoriei, [Herăstrău Park](/wiki/Her%C4%83str%C4%83u_Park "Herăstrău Park"), [Bucureștii Noi](/wiki/Bucure%C8%99tii_Noi "Bucureștii Noi"), Dămăroaia, Străulești, [Grivița](/wiki/Grivi%C8%9Ba "Grivița"), 1 Mai, [Băneasa Forest](/wiki/B%C4%83neasa_Forest "Băneasa Forest"), Pajura, Domenii, Chibrit
* **[Sector 2](/wiki/Sector_2_(Bucharest) "Sector 2 (Bucharest)")** (population 357,338): [Pantelimon](/wiki/Pantelimon,_Bucharest "Pantelimon, Bucharest"), [Colentina](/wiki/Colentina,_Bucharest "Colentina, Bucharest"), [Iancului](/wiki/Iancului "Iancului"), [Tei](/wiki/Tei,_Bucharest "Tei, Bucharest"), [Floreasca](/wiki/Floreasca "Floreasca"), [Moșilor](/wiki/Mo%C8%99ilor "Moșilor"), [Obor](/wiki/Obor "Obor"), Vatra Luminoasă, Fundeni, Plumbuita, Ștefan cel Mare, Baicului
* **[Sector 3](/wiki/Sector_3_(Bucharest) "Sector 3 (Bucharest)")** (population 399,231): [Vitan](/wiki/Vitan,_Bucharest "Vitan, Bucharest"), [Dudești](/wiki/Dude%C8%99ti,_Bucharest "Dudești, Bucharest"), [Titan](/wiki/Titan,_Bucharest "Titan, Bucharest"), [Centrul Civic](/wiki/Centrul_Civic "Centrul Civic"), [Dristor](/wiki/Dristor "Dristor"), [Lipscani](/wiki/Lipscani "Lipscani"), Muncii, Unirii
* **[Sector 4](/wiki/Sector_4_(Bucharest) "Sector 4 (Bucharest)")** (population 300,331): [Berceni](/wiki/Berceni,_Bucharest "Berceni, Bucharest"), [Olteniței](/wiki/Olteni%C8%9Bei "Olteniței"), [Giurgiului](/wiki/Giurgiului "Giurgiului"), [Progresul](/wiki/Progresul "Progresul"), [Văcărești](/wiki/V%C4%83c%C4%83re%C8%99ti,_Bucharest "Văcărești, Bucharest"), Timpuri Noi, Tineretului
* **[Sector 5](/wiki/Sector_5_(Bucharest) "Sector 5 (Bucharest)")** (population 288,690): [Rahova](/wiki/Rahova "Rahova"), [Ferentari](/wiki/Ferentari "Ferentari"), [Giurgiului](/wiki/Giurgiului "Giurgiului"), [Cotroceni](/wiki/Cotroceni "Cotroceni"), 13 Septembrie, Dealul Spirii
* **[Sector 6](/wiki/Sector_6_(Bucharest) "Sector 6 (Bucharest)")** (population 371,060): [Giulești](/wiki/Giule%C8%99ti "Giulești"), [Crângași](/wiki/Cr%C3%A2nga%C8%99i "Crângași"), [Drumul Taberei](/wiki/Drumul_Taberei "Drumul Taberei"), [Militari](/wiki/Militari "Militari"), Grozăvești (also known as Regie), [Ghencea](/wiki/Ghencea "Ghencea")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/71/47%2C_Bulevardul_Regina_Elisabeta%2C_Bucharest_%28Romania%29.jpg/220px-47%2C_Bulevardul_Regina_Elisabeta%2C_Bucharest_%28Romania%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:47,_Bulevardul_Regina_Elisabeta,_Bucharest_(Romania).jpg) The [City Hall of Bucharest](/wiki/Mayor_of_Bucharest "Mayor of Bucharest") in 2020

Each sector is governed by a local mayor, as follows: Sector 1 -- [Clotilde Armand](/wiki/Clotilde_Armand "Clotilde Armand") ([USR](/wiki/Save_Romania_Union "Save Romania Union"), since 2020), Sector 2 -- Radu Mihaiu ([USR](/wiki/Save_Romania_Union "Save Romania Union"), since 2020), Sector 3 -- [Robert Negoiță](/wiki/Robert_Negoi%C8%9B%C4%83 "Robert Negoiță") (PRO B, since 2012), Sector 4 -- Daniel Băluță ([PSD](/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_(Romania) "Social Democratic Party (Romania)"), since 2016), Sector 5 -- Vlad Popescu Piedone (former mayor [Cristian Popescu Piedone](/wiki/Cristian_Popescu_Piedone "Cristian Popescu Piedone")'s son) (PUSL, since 2024),^[\[48\]](#cite_note-48)^ Sector 6 -- Ciprian Ciucu ([PNL](/wiki/National_Liberal_Party_(Romania) "National Liberal Party (Romania)"), since 2020).{#cite_ref-48}

Like all other local councils in Romania, the Bucharest sectoral councils, the capital's [general council](/wiki/General_Council_of_Bucharest "General Council of Bucharest"), and the mayors are elected every four years by the population. Additionally, Bucharest has a [prefect](/wiki/Prefect_(Romania) "Prefect (Romania)"), who is appointed by Romania's national government. The prefect is not allowed to be a member of a political party and his role is to represent the national government at the municipal level. The prefect is acting as a liaison official facilitating the implementation of national development plans and governing programs at local level. The prefect of Bucharest (as of 2024) is Mihai Mugur Toader.^[\[49\]](#cite_note-49)^{#cite_ref-49}

### Justice system {#Justice_system}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Justice system")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Bucharest_-_Palace_of_Justice_%28Justizpalast%29_-_no_filter_%2829340923631%29.jpg/250px-Bucharest_-_Palace_of_Justice_%28Justizpalast%29_-_no_filter_%2829340923631%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bucharest_-_Palace_of_Justice_(Justizpalast)_-_no_filter_(29340923631).jpg) [Palace of Justice](/wiki/Palace_of_Justice,_Bucharest "Palace of Justice, Bucharest") seen across the [Dâmbovița River](/wiki/D%C3%A2mbovi%C8%9Ba_(river) "Dâmbovița (river)") in 2016

Bucharest's judicial system is similar to that of the Romanian counties. Each of the six sectors has its own local first-instance court (*judecătorie* ), while more serious cases are directed to the Bucharest Tribunal (*Tribunalul Bucureşti* ), the city's municipal court. The [Bucharest Court of Appeal](/wiki/Bucharest_Court_of_Appeal "Bucharest Court of Appeal") (*Curtea de Apel Bucureşti* ) judges appeals against decisions taken by first-instance courts and tribunals in Bucharest and in five surrounding counties (Teleorman, Ialomița, Giurgiu, Călărași, and Ilfov). Bucharest is also home to Romania's supreme court, the [High Court of Cassation and Justice](/wiki/High_Court_of_Cassation_and_Justice "High Court of Cassation and Justice"), as well as to the [Constitutional Court of Romania](/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Romania "Constitutional Court of Romania").

Bucharest has a municipal police force, the Bucharest Police (*Poliția București* ), which is responsible for policing crime within the whole city, and operates a number of divisions. The Bucharest Police are headquartered on Ștefan cel Mare Blvd. in the city centre, and at precincts throughout the city. From 2004 onwards, each sector city hall also has under its administration a community police force (*[Poliția Comunitară](/wiki/Poli%C8%9Bia_Comunitar%C4%83 "Poliția Comunitară")* ), dealing with local community issues. Bucharest also houses the general inspectorates of the [*Gendarmerie*](/wiki/Gendarmerie_(Romania) "Gendarmerie (Romania)") and the [national police](/wiki/Romanian_Police "Romanian Police").  

### Crime {#Crime}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Crime")\]  
Main article: [Crime in Bucharest](/wiki/Crime_in_Bucharest "Crime in Bucharest")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Romanian_Police_BMW_3_Series_G20_LCI_3_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-Romanian_Police_BMW_3_Series_G20_LCI_3_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Romanian_Police_BMW_3_Series_G20_LCI_3_(cropped).jpg) A National [Romanian Police](/wiki/Romanian_Police "Romanian Police") car [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Politia_Locala_Bucharest_03.jpg/220px-Politia_Locala_Bucharest_03.jpg)](/wiki/File:Politia_Locala_Bucharest_03.jpg) A car of the Local Police of Bucharest

Bucharest's crime rate is rather low in comparison to other European capital cities, with the number of total offences declining by 51% between 2000 and 2004,^[\[50\]](#cite_note-crimestats-50)^ and by 7% between 2012 and 2013.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-bucurestipolitia2013-51)^ Bucharest, along with [Cluj-Napoca](/wiki/Cluj-Napoca "Cluj-Napoca"), [Timișoara](/wiki/Timi%C8%99oara "Timișoara"), [Brașov](/wiki/Bra%C8%99ov "Brașov") and [Iași](/wiki/Ia%C8%99i "Iași"), was ranked among the top 100 safest cities in the world in a list compiled by Numbeo.^[\[52\]](#cite_note-romania-insider.com-52)^ The study found Bucharest to be very safe with regard to aspects such walking alone, home invasions, muggings, cars being stolen, assault, insults, assault due to skin color, ethnic origin, or gender, drug dealing, and armed robberies, with the only crimes in the high category being corruption and bribery.^[\[52\]](#cite_note-romania-insider.com-52)^ In 2015, the [homicide rate](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_intentional_homicide_rate "List of countries by intentional homicide rate") of Bucharest was 0,8 per 100,000 people.^[\[53\]](#cite_note-53)^{#cite_ref-53}

Crime in Bucharest is combated by national forces, such as the [Romanian Police](/wiki/Romanian_Police "Romanian Police") and [Romanian Gendarmerie](/wiki/Gendarmerie_(Romania) "Gendarmerie (Romania)"), and by local forces, such as the Local Police of Bucharest.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/U.S._%26_Romanian_Forces_Conduct_Bilateral_Training_150225-M-XZ244-318.jpg/220px-U.S._%26_Romanian_Forces_Conduct_Bilateral_Training_150225-M-XZ244-318.jpg)](/wiki/File:U.S._%26_Romanian_Forces_Conduct_Bilateral_Training_150225-M-XZ244-318.jpg) [Romanian Gendarmerie](/wiki/Romanian_Gendarmerie "Romanian Gendarmerie"), which is tasked with high-risk and specialized law enforcement duties, demonstrates room-clearing during a training exercise in Bucharest

Although in the 2000s, a number of police crackdowns on [organised crime](/wiki/Organized_crime "Organized crime") gangs occurred, such as the Cămătaru clan, organised crime generally has little impact on public life. Petty crime, however, is more common, particularly in the form of [pickpocketing](/wiki/Pickpocketing "Pickpocketing"), which occurs mainly on the city's public transport network. [Confidence tricks](/wiki/Confidence_trick "Confidence trick") were common in the 1990s, especially in regards to tourists, but the frequency of these incidents has since declined. Theft was reduced by 13.6% in 2013 compared to 2012.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-bucurestipolitia2013-51)^ Levels of crime are higher in the southern districts of the city, particularly in [Ferentari](/wiki/Ferentari "Ferentari"), a socially disadvantaged area.{#cite_ref-bucurestipolitia2013_51-1}

Although the presence of [street children](/wiki/Street_children "Street children") was a problem in Bucharest in the 1990s, their numbers have declined in recent years, now lying at or below the average of major European capital cities.^[\[54\]](#cite_note-hf-54)^{#cite_ref-hf_54-0}  

### Quality of life {#Quality_of_life}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Quality of life")\]

As stated by the [Mercer](/wiki/Mercer_(consulting_firm) "Mercer (consulting firm)") international surveys for quality of life in cities around the world, Bucharest occupied the 94th place in 2001^[\[55\]](#cite_note-55)^ and slipped lower, to the 108th place in 2009 and the 107th place in 2010. Compared to it, Vienna occupied number one worldwide in 2011 and 2009.^[\[56\]](#cite_note-56)^ Warsaw ranked 84th, Istanbul 112th, and neighbours Sofia 114th and Belgrade 136th (in the 2010 rankings).^[\[57\]](#cite_note-57)^{#cite_ref-57}

Mercer Human Resource Consulting issues yearly a global ranking of the world's most livable cities based on 39 key quality-of-life issues. Among them: political stability, currency-exchange regulations, political and media censorship, school quality, housing, the environment, and public safety. Mercer collects data worldwide, in 215 cities. The difficult situation of the quality of life in Bucharest is confirmed also by a vast urbanism study, done by the [Ion Mincu University of Architecture and Urbanism](/wiki/Ion_Mincu_University_of_Architecture_and_Urbanism "Ion Mincu University of Architecture and Urbanism").^[\[58\]](#cite_note-58)^{#cite_ref-58}

In 2016, Bucharest's urban situation was described as 'critical' by a Romanian Order of Architects (OAR) report that criticised the city's weak, incoherent and arbitrary public management policies, its elected officials' lack of transparency and public engagement, as well as its inadequate and unsustainable use of essential urban resources.^[\[59\]](#cite_note-59)^ Bucharest's historical city centre is listed as 'endangered' by the [World Monuments Watch](/wiki/World_Monuments_Watch "World Monuments Watch") (as of 2016).^[\[14\]](#cite_note-wmf.org-14)^{#cite_ref-wmf.org_14-1}

Although many neighbourhoods, particularly in the southern part of the city, lack sufficient green space, being formed of cramped, high-density blocks of flats, Bucharest also has many [parks](/wiki/Urban_park "Urban park").^[\[60\]](#cite_note-60)^{#cite_ref-60}

In 2024, Bucharest was ranked by the digital publication Freaking Nomads as the 9th best city in the world for [digital nomads](/wiki/Digital_nomad "Digital nomad"), due to its elaborate and diverse architecture, an arts scene featuring some of the world's best galleries, museums, and theatres, and its tranquil parks.^[\[61\]](#cite_note-61)^^[\[62\]](#cite_note-62)^{#cite_ref-62}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Demographics")\]

[Historical population]

As per the [2021 census](/wiki/2021_Romanian_census "2021 Romanian census"), 1,716,961 inhabitants lived within the city limits, a decrease from the figure recorded at the 2011 census.^[\[3\]](#cite_note-RPL2021-3)^ This decrease is due to low natural increase, but also to a shift in population from the city itself to its smaller [satellite towns](/wiki/Satellite_town "Satellite town") such as [Popești-Leordeni](/wiki/Pope%C8%99ti-Leordeni "Popești-Leordeni"), [Voluntari](/wiki/Voluntari "Voluntari"), [Chiajna](/wiki/Chiajna "Chiajna"), [Bragadiru](/wiki/Bragadiru "Bragadiru"), [Pantelimon](/wiki/Pantelimon,_Ilfov "Pantelimon, Ilfov"), [Buftea](/wiki/Buftea "Buftea") and [Otopeni](/wiki/Otopeni "Otopeni"). In a study published by the United Nations, Bucharest placed 19th among 28 cities that recorded sharp declines in population from 1990 to the mid-2010s. In particular, the population fell by 3.77%.^[\[69\]](#cite_note-69)^{#cite_ref-69}

The city's population, according to the 2002 census, was 1,926,334 inhabitants,^[\[70\]](#cite_note-70)^ or 8.9% of the total population of Romania. A significant number of people commute to the city every day, mostly from the surrounding Ilfov County, but official statistics regarding their numbers do not exist.^[\[71\]](#cite_note-71)^{#cite_ref-71}

Bucharest's population experienced two phases of rapid growth, the first beginning in the late 19th century when the city was consolidated as the national capital and lasting until the Second World War, and the second during the Ceaușescu years (1965--1989), when a massive urbanization campaign was launched and many people migrated from rural areas to the capital. At this time, due to Ceaușescu's decision to ban abortion and contraception, [natural increase](/wiki/Natural_increase "Natural increase") was also significant.

Bucharest is a city of high [population density](/wiki/Population_density "Population density"): 8,260/km^2^ (21,400/sq mi),^[\[72\]](#cite_note-72)^ as most of the population lives in high-density communist era [apartment blocks](/wiki/Tower_block#Central_and_Eastern_Europe "Tower block") (*blocuri* ). However, this also depends on the part of the city: the southern boroughs have a higher density than the northern ones. Of the European Union country capital-cities, only [Paris](/wiki/Paris "Paris") and [Athens](/wiki/Athens "Athens") have a higher population density (see [List of European Union cities proper by population density](/wiki/List_of_European_Union_cities_proper_by_population_density "List of European Union cities proper by population density")). In addition to blocks of flats built during the communist era, there are also older interwar ones, as well as newer ones built in the 1990s and in the 21st century. Although apartment buildings are strongly associated with the communist era, such housing schemes were first introduced in Bucharest in the 1920s.^[\[73\]](#cite_note-73)^{#cite_ref-73}

About 97.3% of the population of Bucharest for whom data are available is [Romanian](/wiki/Romanians "Romanians").^[\[74\]](#cite_note-74)^ Other significant ethnic groups are [Romani](/wiki/Romani_people "Romani people"), Hungarians, Turks, [Jews](/wiki/Jews "Jews"), [Germans](/wiki/Germans_of_Romania "Germans of Romania") (mostly [Regat Germans](/wiki/Regat_Germans "Regat Germans")), Chinese, Russians, Ukrainians, and Italians. A relatively small number of Bucharesters are also [Greeks](/wiki/Greeks_in_Romania "Greeks in Romania"), Armenians, Kurds, Bulgarians, Albanians, Poles, French, Arabs, Africans (including the [Afro-Romanians](/wiki/Afro-Romanians "Afro-Romanians")), Iranians, Vietnamese, Filipinos, Nepalis, Afghans, Sri Lankans, Bangladeshis, Pakistanis, and Indians.^[\[75\]](#cite_note-75)^^[\[76\]](#cite_note-76)^^[\[77\]](#cite_note-77)^^[\[78\]](#cite_note-78)^^[\[79\]](#cite_note-79)^^[\[80\]](#cite_note-80)^^[\[81\]](#cite_note-81)^ 226,943 people did not declare their ethnicity.^[\[82\]](#cite_note-82)^^[\[83\]](#cite_note-83)^{#cite_ref-83}

In terms of religious affiliation, 96.1% of the population for whom data are available is [Romanian Orthodox](/wiki/Romanian_Orthodox_Church "Romanian Orthodox Church"), 1.2% is [Roman Catholic](/wiki/Romanian_Roman-Catholic_Church "Romanian Roman-Catholic Church"), 0.5% is [Muslim](/wiki/Islam_in_Romania "Islam in Romania"), and 0.4% is [Romanian Greek Catholic](/wiki/Romanian_Church_United_with_Rome,_Greek-Catholic "Romanian Church United with Rome, Greek-Catholic"). Despite this, only 18% of the population, of any religion, attends a place of worship once a week or more.^[\[84\]](#cite_note-84)^ The life expectancy of residents of Bucharest in 2015 was 77.8 years old, which is 2.4 years above the national average.^[\[85\]](#cite_note-85)^{#cite_ref-85}  

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Economy")\]  
Main article: [Economy of Bucharest](/wiki/Economy_of_Bucharest "Economy of Bucharest")

Bucharest is the centre of the Romanian economy and industry, accounting for around 24% (2017) of the country's GDP and about one-quarter of its industrial production, while being inhabited by 9% of the country's population.^[\[86\]](#cite_note-86)^ Almost one-third of national taxes is paid by Bucharest's citizens and companies.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ The living standard in the Bucharest--Ilfov region was 145% of the EU average in 2017, according to GDP per capita at the [purchasing power parity](/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity "Purchasing power parity") standard (adjusted to the national price level).{#cite_ref-86}

The Bucharest area surpassed, on comparable terms, European metropolitan areas such as [Budapest](/wiki/Budapest "Budapest") (139%), [Madrid](/wiki/Madrid "Madrid") (125%), [Berlin](/wiki/Berlin "Berlin") (118%), [Rome](/wiki/Rome "Rome") (110%), [Lisbon](/wiki/Lisbon "Lisbon") (102%), and [Sofia](/wiki/Sofia "Sofia") (79%), and more than twice the Romanian average.^[\[87\]](#cite_note-ec.europa.eu-87)^^\[*[clarification needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please clarify")*\]^ After relative stagnation in the 1990s, the city's strong economic growth has revitalised infrastructure and led to the development of shopping malls, residential estates, and high-rise office buildings. In January 2013, Bucharest had an unemployment rate of 2.1%, significantly lower than the national unemployment rate of 5.8%.^[\[88\]](#cite_note-88)^^[\[89\]](#cite_note-89)^{#cite_ref-89}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Bucharest_Business_District.jpg/220px-Bucharest_Business_District.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bucharest_Business_District.jpg) [Floreasca City Center](/wiki/Floreasca_City_Center "Floreasca City Center") business district, as seen from [Lake Herăstrău](/wiki/Lake_Her%C4%83str%C4%83u "Lake Herăstrău").

Bucharest's economy is centred on industry and [services](/wiki/Service_Sector "Service Sector"), with services particularly growing in importance in the past 10 years. The headquarters of 186,000 firms, including nearly all large Romanian companies, are located in Bucharest.^[\[90\]](#cite_note-90)^ An important source of growth since 2000 has been the city's rapidly expanding property and construction sector. Bucharest is also Romania's largest centre for information technology and communications and is home to several software companies operating offshore delivery centres. Romania's largest stock exchange, the [Bucharest Stock Exchange](/wiki/Bucharest_Stock_Exchange "Bucharest Stock Exchange"), which was merged in December 2005 with the Bucharest-based electronic stock exchange [Rasdaq](/wiki/Rasdaq "Rasdaq"), plays a major role in the city's economy.{#cite_ref-90}

Malls and large shopping centres have been built since the late 1990s, such as [Băneasa Shopping City](/wiki/B%C4%83neasa_Shopping_City "Băneasa Shopping City"), [AFI Palace Cotroceni](/wiki/AFI_Palace_Cotroceni "AFI Palace Cotroceni"), Mega Mall, [București Mall](/wiki/Bucure%C8%99ti_Mall "București Mall"), ParkLake Shopping Centre, [Sun Plaza](/wiki/Sun_Plaza_(Bucharest) "Sun Plaza (Bucharest)"), Promenada Mall and longest [Unirea Shopping Centre](/wiki/Unirea_Shopping_Center "Unirea Shopping Center"). Bucharest has [over 20 malls](/wiki/List_of_shopping_malls_in_Romania "List of shopping malls in Romania") as of 2019.^[\[91\]](#cite_note-91)^^[\[92\]](#cite_note-92)^{#cite_ref-92}

The corporations [Amazon](/wiki/Amazon_(company) "Amazon (company)"), [Microsoft](/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft"), [Ubisoft](/wiki/Ubisoft_Bucharest "Ubisoft Bucharest"), [Oracle Corporation](/wiki/Oracle_Corporation "Oracle Corporation"), or [IBM](/wiki/IBM "IBM") are all present in the Romanian capital. The top ten is also dominated by companies operating in automotive, oil \& gas (such as [Petrom](/wiki/Petrom "Petrom")), as well as companies in telecommunication and [FMCG](/wiki/Fast-moving_consumer_goods "Fast-moving consumer goods").^[\[93\]](#cite_note-93)^^[\[94\]](#cite_note-94)^ The [Speedtest](/wiki/Speedtest.net "Speedtest.net") Global Index ranks Bucharest the 6th city in the world (after [Beijing](/wiki/Beijing "Beijing"), [Shanghai](/wiki/Shanghai "Shanghai"), [Abu Dhabi](/wiki/Abu_Dhabi "Abu Dhabi"), [Valparaíso](/wiki/Valpara%C3%ADso "Valparaíso"), and [Lyon](/wiki/Lyon "Lyon")) in terms of fixed [broadband](/wiki/Broadband "Broadband") speed, at 250[Mbps](/wiki/Data-rate_units "Data-rate units") as of 2023.^[\[95\]](#cite_note-95)^{#cite_ref-95}

Transport {#Transport}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Transport")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Bucharest_Metro_stationed_in_Eroilor_2_Station.jpg/220px-Bucharest_Metro_stationed_in_Eroilor_2_Station.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bucharest_Metro_stationed_in_Eroilor_2_Station.jpg) [Bucharest Metro](/wiki/Bucharest_Metro "Bucharest Metro") has 64 stations.

Bucharest is crossed by two major international routes: [Pan-European transport corridor](/wiki/Pan-European_corridors "Pan-European corridors") [IV](/wiki/Pan-European_Corridor_IV "Pan-European Corridor IV") and [IX](/wiki/Pan-European_Corridor_IX "Pan-European Corridor IX").  

### Public transport {#Public_transport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Public transport")\]  
Main article: [Transport in Bucharest](/wiki/Transport_in_Bucharest "Transport in Bucharest")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Otokar_Kent_C_6556_at_Universitate.jpg/220px-Otokar_Kent_C_6556_at_Universitate.jpg)](/wiki/File:Otokar_Kent_C_6556_at_Universitate.jpg) [Otokar Kent](/wiki/Otokar_Kent "Otokar Kent") bus at the Universitate junction  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Metro_Bucure%C8%99ti.svg/200px-Metro_Bucure%C8%99ti.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Metro_Bucure%C8%99ti.svg)  
Bucharest Metro Network Map

Bucharest's public transport system is the largest in Romania and one of the largest in Europe. It is made up of the [Bucharest Metro](/wiki/Bucharest_Metro "Bucharest Metro"), run by [Metrorex](/wiki/Metrorex "Metrorex"), as well as a surface transport system run by [STB](/wiki/RATB "RATB") (*Societatea de Transport București* , previously known as the RATB), which consists of buses, [trams](/wiki/Trams_in_Bucharest "Trams in Bucharest"), [trolleybuses](/wiki/Trolleybus "Trolleybus"), and [light rail](/wiki/Bucharest_Light_rail "Bucharest Light rail"). In addition, a private [minibus system](/wiki/Marshrutka#The_South_Caucasus_states "Marshrutka") operates there. As of 2007^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit)^, a limit of 10,000 taxicab licences was imposed.^[\[96\]](#cite_note-96)^{#cite_ref-96}

The Bucharest Metro consists of five lines ([M1](/wiki/M1_Line_(Bucharest_Metro) "M1 Line (Bucharest Metro)"), [M2](/wiki/M2_Line "M2 Line"), [M3](/wiki/M3_Line "M3 Line"), [M4](/wiki/Bucharest_Metro_Line_M4 "Bucharest Metro Line M4"), and [M5](/wiki/Bucharest_Metro_Line_M5 "Bucharest Metro Line M5")) ran by [Metrorex](/wiki/Metrorex "Metrorex"), and is one of the fastest ways to get around the city. The oldest metro line is M1, which was opened in 1979.^[\[97\]](#cite_note-97)^ The newest metro line is M5, which was opened in 2020.^[\[98\]](#cite_note-98)^ A sixth metro line, [M6](/wiki/Bucharest_Metro_Line_M6 "Bucharest Metro Line M6") line, is currently under construction.{#cite_ref-98}  

### Railways {#Railways}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Railways")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Exterior_of_the_Bucharest_North_Station_%2804%29.jpg/220px-Exterior_of_the_Bucharest_North_Station_%2804%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Exterior_of_the_Bucharest_North_Station_(04).jpg) [Gara de Nord](/wiki/Gara_de_Nord "Gara de Nord") (North Railway Station)

It is the hub of Romania's national railway network, run by *[Căile Ferate Române](/wiki/C%C4%83ile_Ferate_Rom%C3%A2ne "Căile Ferate Române")* . The main railway station is [Gara de Nord](/wiki/Gara_de_Nord "Gara de Nord") ('North Station'), which provides connections to all major cities in Romania, as well as international destinations: [Belgrade](/wiki/Belgrade "Belgrade"), [Sofia](/wiki/Sofia "Sofia"), [Varna](/wiki/Varna,_Bulgaria "Varna, Bulgaria"), [Chișinău](/wiki/Chi%C8%99in%C4%83u "Chișinău"), [Kyiv](/wiki/Kyiv "Kyiv"), [Chernivtsi](/wiki/Chernivtsi "Chernivtsi"), [Lviv](/wiki/Lviv "Lviv"), [Thessaloniki](/wiki/Thessaloniki "Thessaloniki"), [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna"), [Budapest](/wiki/Budapest "Budapest"), [Istanbul](/wiki/Istanbul "Istanbul"), [Moscow](/wiki/Moscow "Moscow"), etc.

The city has five other railway stations run by CFR, of which the most important are Basarab (adjacent to North Station), Obor, Băneasa, and Progresul. These are in the process of being integrated into a commuter railway serving Bucharest and the surrounding [Ilfov County](/wiki/Ilfov_County "Ilfov County"). Seven main lines radiate out of Bucharest.

The oldest station in Bucharest is Filaret. It was inaugurated in 1869, and in 1960, the communist government turned it in a bus terminal.^[\[99\]](#cite_note-99)^{#cite_ref-99}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Otopeni-henri-coanda-airport-march-2013.jpg/260px-Otopeni-henri-coanda-airport-march-2013.jpg)](/wiki/File:Otopeni-henri-coanda-airport-march-2013.jpg) Henri Coandă International Airport  

### Air {#Air}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Air")\]

* [Henri Coandă International Airport](/wiki/Henri_Coand%C4%83_International_Airport "Henri Coandă International Airport") ([IATA](/wiki/IATA "IATA"): OTP, [ICAO](/wiki/ICAO "ICAO"): LROP), located 16.5 km (10.3 mi) north of the Bucharest city centre, in the town of [Otopeni](/wiki/Otopeni "Otopeni"), Ilfov. It is the busiest airport in Romania, in terms of passenger traffic: 12,807,032 in 2017.^[\[100\]](#cite_note-100)^{#cite_ref-100}
* [Aurel Vlaicu International Airport](/wiki/Aurel_Vlaicu_International_Airport "Aurel Vlaicu International Airport") (IATA: BBU, ICAO: LRBS) is Bucharest's business and VIP airport. It is situated only 8 km (5.0 mi) north of the Bucharest city centre, within city limits.

### Roads {#Roads}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Roads")\]

Bucharest is a major intersection of [Romania's national road network](/wiki/Roads_in_Romania "Roads in Romania"). A few of the busiest national roads and motorways link the city to all of Romania's major cities, as well as to neighbouring countries such as Hungary, Bulgaria and Ukraine. The [A1](/wiki/A1_freeway_(Romania) "A1 freeway (Romania)") to Pitești, and from Sibiu to the Hungarian border, the [A2 Sun Motorway](/wiki/A2_motorway_(Romania) "A2 motorway (Romania)") to the Dobrogea region and Constanța, and the [A3](/wiki/A3_freeway_(Romania) "A3 freeway (Romania)") to Ploiești all start from Bucharest.

A series of high-capacity boulevards, which generally radiate out from the city centre to the outskirts, provides a framework for the municipal road system. The main axes, which run north--south, east--west and northwest--southeast, as well as one internal and one external ring road, support the bulk of the traffic.

The city's roads are usually very crowded during rush hours, due to an increase in car ownership in recent years. In 2013, the number of cars registered in Bucharest amounted to 1,125,591.^[\[101\]](#cite_note-101)^ This results in wear and [potholes](/wiki/Pothole "Pothole") appearing on busy roads, particularly secondary roads, this being identified as one of Bucharest's main infrastructural problems. A comprehensive effort on behalf of the City Hall to boost road infrastructure was made, and according to the general development plan, 2,000 roads have been repaired by 2008.^[\[102\]](#cite_note-102)^ The huge number of cars registered in the city forced the Romanian Auto Registry to switch to 3-digit numbers on [registration plates](/wiki/Vehicle_registration_plates_of_Romania "Vehicle registration plates of Romania") in 2010.{#cite_ref-102}

On 17 June 2011, the [Basarab Overpass](/wiki/Basarab_Overpass "Basarab Overpass") was inaugurated and opened to traffic, thus completing the inner city traffic ring. The overpass took five years to build and is the longest [cable-stayed bridge](/wiki/Cable-stayed_bridge "Cable-stayed bridge") in Romania and the widest such bridge in Europe;^[\[103\]](#cite_note-103)^ upon completion, traffic on the [Grant Bridge](/wiki/Grant_Bridge "Grant Bridge") and in the Gara de Nord area became noticeably more fluid.^[\[104\]](#cite_note-104)^{#cite_ref-104}

### Water {#Water}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Water")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Dambovita_near_Ciurel_Bridge_in_Bucharest.jpg/220px-Dambovita_near_Ciurel_Bridge_in_Bucharest.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dambovita_near_Ciurel_Bridge_in_Bucharest.jpg) [Dâmbovița](/wiki/D%C3%A2mbovi%C8%9Ba_(river) "Dâmbovița (river)") river in Bucharest

Although it is situated on the banks of a river, Bucharest has never functioned as a port city. Other Romanian cities such as [Constanța](/wiki/Constan%C8%9Ba "Constanța") and [Galați](/wiki/Gala%C8%9Bi "Galați") serve as the country's main ports. The unfinished [Danube-Bucharest Canal](/wiki/Danube-Bucharest_Canal "Danube-Bucharest Canal"), which is 73 km (45 mi) long and around 70% completed, could link Bucharest to the [Danube River](/wiki/Danube_River "Danube River"), and via the [Danube-Black Sea Canal](/wiki/Danube-Black_Sea_Canal "Danube-Black Sea Canal"), to the [Black Sea](/wiki/Black_Sea "Black Sea"). Works on the canal were suspended in 1989, but proposals have been made to resume construction as part of the European Strategy for the Danube Region.^[\[105\]](#cite_note-105)^{#cite_ref-105}  

Culture {#Culture}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Culture")\]  
Main article: [Culture of Romania](/wiki/Culture_of_Romania "Culture of Romania")

Bucharest has a growing cultural scene, in fields including the visual arts, performing arts, and nightlife. Unlike other parts of Romania, such as the Black Sea coast or [Transylvania](/wiki/Transylvania "Transylvania"), Bucharest's cultural scene has no defined style, and instead incorporates elements of Romanian and international culture.  

### Landmarks {#Landmarks}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Landmarks")\]

Bucharest has landmark buildings and monuments. Perhaps the most prominent of these is the [Palace of the Parliament](/wiki/Palace_of_the_Parliament "Palace of the Parliament"), built in the 1980s during the rule of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceaușescu. The [largest Parliament building](/wiki/List_of_largest_buildings_in_the_world#Special_categories "List of largest buildings in the world") in the world, the palace houses the Romanian Parliament (the [Chamber of Deputies](/wiki/Chamber_of_Deputies_of_Romania "Chamber of Deputies of Romania"), and the [Senate](/wiki/Senate_of_Romania "Senate of Romania")), as well as the [National Museum of Contemporary Art](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Contemporary_Art_(Romania) "National Museum of Contemporary Art (Romania)"). The building boasts one of the largest convention centres in the world.

Another landmark in Bucharest is [Arcul de Triumf](/wiki/Arcul_de_Triumf "Arcul de Triumf") ("The Triumphal Arch"), built in its current form in 1935 and modelled after the [Arc de Triomphe](/wiki/Arc_de_Triomphe "Arc de Triomphe") in Paris. A newer landmark of the city is the [Memorial of Rebirth](/wiki/Memorial_of_Rebirth "Memorial of Rebirth"), a stylised marble pillar unveiled in 2005 to commemorate the victims of the [Romanian Revolution](/wiki/Romanian_Revolution "Romanian Revolution") of 1989, which overthrew Communism. The abstract monument sparked controversy when it was unveiled, being dubbed with names such as 'the olive on the toothpick' (*măslina-n scobitoare* ), as many argued that it does not fit in its surroundings and believed that its choice was political.^[\[106\]](#cite_note-106)^{#cite_ref-106}

The [Romanian Athenaeum](/wiki/Romanian_Athenaeum "Romanian Athenaeum") building is considered a symbol of Romanian culture and since 2007 has been on the list of the Label of European Heritage sites. It was built between 1886 and 1888 by the architect Paul Louis Albert Galeron, through public funding.^[\[107\]](#cite_note-107)^^[\[108\]](#cite_note-108)^{#cite_ref-108}

[InterContinental Bucharest](/wiki/InterContinental_Bucharest "InterContinental Bucharest") is a high-rise five-star hotel near University Square and is also a landmark of the city. The building is designed so that each room has a unique panorama of the city.^[\[109\]](#cite_note-109)^{#cite_ref-109}

[House of the Spark](/wiki/House_of_the_Free_Press "House of the Free Press") (*Casa Scânteii* ) is a replica of the [Lomonosov Moscow State University](/wiki/Lomonosov_Moscow_State_University "Lomonosov Moscow State University"). This edifice, built in the characteristic style of the large-scale Soviet projects, was intended to be representative of the new political regime and to assert the superiority of the Communist doctrine. Construction started in 1952 and was completed in 1957, a few years after Stalin's death in 1953. Popularly known as Casa Scânteii ('House of the Spark') after the name of the official gazette of the Central Committee of the Romanian Communist Party, *Scânteia* , it was made for the purpose of bringing together under one roof all of Bucharest's official press and publishing houses. It is the only building in Bucharest featuring the [Hammer and Sickle](/wiki/Hammer_and_Sickle "Hammer and Sickle"), the Red Star and other communist insignia carved into medallions adorning the façade.

Other cultural venues include the [National Museum of Art of Romania](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Art_of_Romania "National Museum of Art of Romania"), [Grigore Antipa National Museum of Natural History](/wiki/Grigore_Antipa_National_Museum_of_Natural_History "Grigore Antipa National Museum of Natural History"), [Museum of the Romanian Peasant](/wiki/Museum_of_the_Romanian_Peasant "Museum of the Romanian Peasant"), [National History Museum](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Romanian_History "National Museum of Romanian History") and the [Military Museum](/wiki/National_Military_Museum_(Romania) "National Military Museum (Romania)").
