### Visual arts {#Visual_arts}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Visual arts")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/The_Royal_Palace_%28AP4K1357_1PS%29_%2829291577856%29.jpg/220px-The_Royal_Palace_%28AP4K1357_1PS%29_%2829291577856%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_Royal_Palace_(AP4K1357_1PS)_(29291577856).jpg) [National Museum of Art of Romania](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Art_of_Romania "National Museum of Art of Romania") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Bucuresti%2C_Romania%2C_Muzeul_National_de_Istorie_Naturala_Grigore_Antipa%3B_B-II-m-A-18983_%28Interior%2C_detaliu_31%29.JPG/220px-Bucuresti%2C_Romania%2C_Muzeul_National_de_Istorie_Naturala_Grigore_Antipa%3B_B-II-m-A-18983_%28Interior%2C_detaliu_31%29.JPG)](/wiki/File:Bucuresti,_Romania,_Muzeul_National_de_Istorie_Naturala_Grigore_Antipa;_B-II-m-A-18983_(Interior,_detaliu_31).JPG) [Grigore Antipa National Museum of Natural History](/wiki/Grigore_Antipa_National_Museum_of_Natural_History "Grigore Antipa National Museum of Natural History")

In terms of [visual arts](/wiki/Visual_arts "Visual arts"), the city has museums featuring both classical and contemporary Romanian art, as well as selected international works. The [National Museum of Art of Romania](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Art_of_Romania "National Museum of Art of Romania") is perhaps the best-known of Bucharest museums. It is located in the royal palace and features collections of medieval and modern Romanian art, including works by sculptor [Constantin Brâncuși](/wiki/Constantin_Br%C3%A2ncu%C8%99i "Constantin Brâncuși"), as well as an international collection assembled by the Romanian royal family.

Other, smaller, museums contain specialised collections. The [Zambaccian Museum](/wiki/Zambaccian_Museum "Zambaccian Museum"), which is situated in the former home of art collector Krikor H. Zambaccian, contains works by well-known Romanian artists and international artists such as [Paul Cézanne](/wiki/Paul_C%C3%A9zanne "Paul Cézanne"), [Eugène Delacroix](/wiki/Eug%C3%A8ne_Delacroix "Eugène Delacroix"), [Henri Matisse](/wiki/Henri_Matisse "Henri Matisse"), [Camille Pissarro](/wiki/Camille_Pissarro "Camille Pissarro"), and [Pablo Picasso](/wiki/Pablo_Picasso "Pablo Picasso").

The [Gheorghe Tattarescu](/wiki/Gheorghe_Tattarescu "Gheorghe Tattarescu") Museum contains portraits of Romanian revolutionaries in exile such as [Gheorghe Magheru](/wiki/Gheorghe_Magheru "Gheorghe Magheru"), [ștefan Golescu](/wiki/%C8%98tefan_Golescu "Ștefan Golescu"), and [Nicolae Bălcescu](/wiki/Nicolae_B%C4%83lcescu "Nicolae Bălcescu"), and allegorical compositions with revolutionary (*Romania's rebirth* , 1849) and patriotic (*The [Principalities' Unification](/wiki/Danubian_Principalities#United_Principalities "Danubian Principalities")*, 1857) themes. Another impressive art collection gathering important Romanian painters, can be found at the Ligia and Pompiliu Macovei residence, which is open to visitors as it is now part of the Bucharest Museum patrimony.

The [Theodor Pallady Museum](/wiki/Theodor_Pallady_Museum "Theodor Pallady Museum") is situated in one of the oldest surviving merchant houses in Bucharest and includes works by Romanian painter [Theodor Pallady](/wiki/Theodor_Pallady "Theodor Pallady"), as well as European and oriental furniture pieces. The [Museum of Art Collections](/wiki/Museum_of_Art_Collections "Museum of Art Collections") contains the collections of Romanian art aficionados, including Krikor Zambaccian and Theodor Pallady.

Despite the classical art galleries and museums in the city, a contemporary arts scene also exists. The [National Museum of Contemporary Art](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Contemporary_Art_(Romania) "National Museum of Contemporary Art (Romania)") (MNAC), situated in a wing of the [Palace of the Parliament](/wiki/Palace_of_the_Parliament "Palace of the Parliament"), was opened in 2004 and contains Romanian and international contemporary art. The MNAC also manages the Kalinderu MediaLab, which caters to multimedia and experimental art. Private art galleries are scattered throughout the city centre.

The palace of the [National Bank of Romania](/wiki/National_Bank_of_Romania "National Bank of Romania") houses the national [numismatic](/wiki/Numismatic "Numismatic") collection. Exhibits include banknotes, coins, documents, photographs, maps, silver and gold bullion bars, bullion coins, and dies and moulds. The building was constructed between 1884 and 1890. The thesaurus room contains notable marble decorations.  

### Performing arts {#Performing_arts}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Performing arts")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Bucuresti%2C_Romania._Teatrul_ODEON._Zi_de_vara._Biciclista._%28B-II-m-B-19854%29.jpg/220px-Bucuresti%2C_Romania._Teatrul_ODEON._Zi_de_vara._Biciclista._%28B-II-m-B-19854%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bucuresti,_Romania._Teatrul_ODEON._Zi_de_vara._Biciclista._(B-II-m-B-19854).jpg) [Odeon Theatre](/wiki/Odeon_Theatre_(Bucharest) "Odeon Theatre (Bucharest)") in June 2018

[Performing arts](/wiki/Performing_arts "Performing arts") are some of the strongest cultural elements of Bucharest. The most famous symphony orchestra is [National Radio Orchestra of Romania](/wiki/National_Radio_Orchestra_of_Romania "National Radio Orchestra of Romania"). One of the most prominent buildings is the neoclassical [Romanian Athenaeum](/wiki/Romanian_Athenaeum "Romanian Athenaeum"), which was founded in 1852, and hosts classical music concerts, the [George Enescu Festival](/wiki/George_Enescu_Festival "George Enescu Festival"), and is home to the [George Enescu Philharmonic Orchestra](/wiki/George_Enescu_Philharmonic_Orchestra "George Enescu Philharmonic Orchestra").

Bucharest is home to the [Romanian National Opera](/wiki/Romanian_National_Opera,_Bucharest "Romanian National Opera, Bucharest") and the [I.L. Caragiale National Theatre](/wiki/I.L._Caragiale_National_Theatre "I.L. Caragiale National Theatre"). Another well-known theatre in Bucharest is the [State Jewish Theatre](/wiki/State_Jewish_Theater_(Romania) "State Jewish Theater (Romania)"), which features plays starring world-renowned Romanian-Jewish actress [Maia Morgenstern](/wiki/Maia_Morgenstern "Maia Morgenstern"). Smaller theatres throughout the city cater to specific genres, such as the Comedy Theatre, the Nottara Theatre, the [Bulandra Theatre](/wiki/Bulandra_Theatre "Bulandra Theatre"), the [Odeon Theatre](/wiki/Odeon_Theatre_(Bucharest) "Odeon Theatre (Bucharest)"), and the revue theatre of [Constantin Tănase](/wiki/Constantin_T%C4%83nase "Constantin Tănase").  

### Music and nightlife {#Music_and_nightlife}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Music and nightlife")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Liscani_Street_3.jpg/220px-Liscani_Street_3.jpg)](/wiki/File:Liscani_Street_3.jpg) The [Old Town](/wiki/Bucharest_Old_Town "Bucharest Old Town") is the heart of Bucharest nightlife.

Bucharest is home to Romania's largest recording labels, and is often the residence of Romanian musicians. Romanian rock bands of the 1970s and 1980s, such as [Iris](/wiki/IRIS_(Romanian_band) "IRIS (Romanian band)") and Holograf, continue to be popular, particularly with the middle-aged, while since the beginning of the 1990s, the [hip hop](/wiki/Hip_hop_music "Hip hop music")/[rap](/wiki/Rapping "Rapping") scene has developed. Hip-hop bands and artists from Bucharest such as [B.U.G. Mafia](/wiki/B.U.G._Mafia "B.U.G. Mafia"), [Paraziții](/wiki/Parazi%C8%9Bii "Paraziții"), and [La Familia](/wiki/La_Familia_(rap_group) "La Familia (rap group)") enjoy national and international recognition.

The pop-rock band [Taxi](/wiki/Taxi_(Romanian_band) "Taxi (Romanian band)") have been gaining international respect, as has [Spitalul de Urgență](/wiki/Spitalul_de_Urgen%C8%9B%C4%83 "Spitalul de Urgență")'s raucous updating of traditional [Romanian music](/wiki/Music_of_Romania "Music of Romania"). While many neighbourhood [discos](/wiki/Discoth%C3%A8que "Discothèque") play *[manele](/wiki/Manele "Manele")* , an Oriental- and Roma-influenced genre of music that is particularly popular in Bucharest's working-class districts, the city has a rich [jazz](/wiki/Jazz "Jazz") and [blues](/wiki/Blues "Blues") scene, and to an even larger extent, [house music](/wiki/House_music "House music")/[trance](/wiki/Trance_music "Trance music") and [heavy metal](/wiki/Heavy_metal_music "Heavy metal music")/[punk](/wiki/Punk_music "Punk music") scenes. Bucharest's jazz profile has especially risen since 2002, with the presence of two venues, Green Hours and Art Jazz, as well as an American presence alongside established Romanians.

With no central nightlife strip, entertainment venues are dispersed throughout the city, with clusters in [Lipscani](/wiki/Lipscani "Lipscani") and [Regie](/wiki/Regie,_Bucharest "Regie, Bucharest").  

### Cultural events and festivals {#Cultural_events_and_festivals}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Cultural events and festivals")\]

A number of cultural festivals are held in Bucharest throughout the year, but most festivals take place in June, July, and August. The National Opera organises the International Opera Festival every year in May and June, which includes ensembles and orchestras from all over the world.

The Romanian Athaeneum Society hosts the [George Enescu Festival](/wiki/George_Enescu_Festival "George Enescu Festival") at locations throughout the city in September every two years (odd years). The Museum of the Romanian Peasant and the Village Museum organise events throughout the year, showcasing Romanian folk arts and crafts.

In the 2000s, due to the growing prominence of the Chinese community in Bucharest, Chinese cultural events took place. The first officially organised Chinese festival was the [Chinese New Year](/wiki/Chinese_New_Year "Chinese New Year")'s Eve Festival of February 2005, which took place in Nichita Stănescu Park and was organised by the Bucharest City Hall.^[\[115\]](#cite_note-115)^{#cite_ref-115}

In 2005, Bucharest was the first city in Southeastern Europe to host the international [CowParade](/wiki/CowParade "CowParade"), which resulted in dozens of decorated cow sculptures being placed across the city.

In 2004, Bucharest imposed in the circle of important festivals in Eastern Europe with the Bucharest International Film Festival, an event widely acknowledged in Europe, having as guests of honour famous names from the world cinema: [Andrei Konchalovsky](/wiki/Andrei_Konchalovsky "Andrei Konchalovsky"), [Danis Tanović](/wiki/Danis_Tanovi%C4%87 "Danis Tanović"), [Nikita Mikhalkov](/wiki/Nikita_Mikhalkov "Nikita Mikhalkov"), [Rutger Hauer](/wiki/Rutger_Hauer "Rutger Hauer"), [Jerzy Skolimowski](/wiki/Jerzy_Skolimowski "Jerzy Skolimowski"), [Jan Harlan](/wiki/Jan_Harlan "Jan Harlan"), [Radu Mihăileanu](/wiki/Radu_Mih%C4%83ileanu "Radu Mihăileanu"), and many others.^[\[116\]](#cite_note-116)^{#cite_ref-116}

Since 2005, Bucharest has its own contemporary [art biennale](/wiki/Art_exhibition "Art exhibition"), the [Bucharest Biennale](/wiki/Bucharest_Biennale "Bucharest Biennale").

### Traditional culture {#Traditional_culture}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Traditional culture")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Bucarest_Musee_national_du_village56.JPG/220px-Bucarest_Musee_national_du_village56.JPG)](/wiki/File:Bucarest_Musee_national_du_village56.JPG) Traditional wooden church at the [Village Museum](/wiki/Dimitrie_Gusti_National_Village_Museum "Dimitrie Gusti National Village Museum")

Traditional Romanian culture continues to have a major influence in arts such as theatre, film, and music. Bucharest has two internationally renowned [ethnographic](/wiki/Ethnography "Ethnography") museums, the [Museum of the Romanian Peasant](/wiki/Museum_of_the_Romanian_Peasant "Museum of the Romanian Peasant") and the open-air [Dimitrie Gusti National Village Museum](/wiki/Dimitrie_Gusti_National_Village_Museum_in_Bucharest "Dimitrie Gusti National Village Museum in Bucharest"), in [King Michael I Park](/wiki/King_Michael_I_Park "King Michael I Park"). It contains 272 authentic buildings and peasant farms from all over Romania.^[\[117\]](#cite_note-117)^{#cite_ref-117}

The Museum of the Romanian Peasant was declared the European Museum of the Year in 1996. Patronised by the Ministry of Culture, the museum preserves and exhibits numerous collections of objects and monuments of material and spiritual culture. The Museum of the Romanian Peasant holds one of the richest collections of peasant objects in Romania, its heritage being nearly 90,000 pieces, those being divided into several collections: ceramics, costumes, textiles, wooden objects, religious objects, customs, etc.^[\[118\]](#cite_note-118)^{#cite_ref-118}

The [Museum of Romanian History](/wiki/Museum_of_Romanian_History "Museum of Romanian History") is another important museum in Bucharest, containing a collection of artefacts detailing Romanian history and culture from the prehistoric times, [Dacian](/wiki/Dacia "Dacia") era, medieval times, and the modern era.  

### Religion {#Religion}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Religion")\]

Bucharest is the seat of the Patriarch of the [Romanian Orthodox Church](/wiki/Romanian_Orthodox_Church "Romanian Orthodox Church"), one of the [Eastern Orthodox](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox "Eastern Orthodox") churches in communion with the [Patriarch of Constantinople](/wiki/Ecumenical_Patriarch_of_Constantinople "Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople"), and also of its subdivisions, the Metropolis of Muntenia and Dobrudja and the Archbishopric of Bucharest. Orthodox believers consider Demetrius of Basarabov to be the patron saint of the city.

The city is a centre for other Christian organizations in Romania, including the [Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Bucharest](/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Archdiocese_of_Bucharest "Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Bucharest"), established in 1883, and the [Romanian Greek-Catholic](/wiki/Romanian_Church_United_with_Rome,_Greek-Catholic "Romanian Church United with Rome, Greek-Catholic") [Eparchy of Saint Basil the Great](/wiki/Romanian_Catholic_Eparchy_of_Bucharest "Romanian Catholic Eparchy of Bucharest"), founded in 2014.

Bucharest also hosts six synagogues, including the [Choral Temple of Bucharest](/wiki/Templul_Coral "Templul Coral"), the [Great Synagogue of Bucharest](/wiki/Great_Synagogue_(Bucharest) "Great Synagogue (Bucharest)") and the [Holy Union Temple](/wiki/Jewish_Museum_(Bucharest) "Jewish Museum (Bucharest)"). The latter was converted into the Museum of the History of the Romanian Jewish Community, while the Great Synagogue and the Choral Temple are both active and hold regular services.^[\[119\]](#cite_note-119)^{#cite_ref-119}

A [mosque](/wiki/Grand_Mosque_of_Bucharest "Grand Mosque of Bucharest") with a capacity for 2,000 people^[\[120\]](#cite_note-120)^ was in the planning stages at 22--30 Expoziției Boulevard. The project was later abandoned.^[\[121\]](#cite_note-121)^ However, there are several smaller [Sunni](/wiki/Sunni_Islam "Sunni Islam") and [Shia](/wiki/Shia_Islam "Shia Islam") mosques active in Bucharest.^[\[122\]](#cite_note-122)^{#cite_ref-122}

Architecture {#Architecture}
----------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Architecture")\]

The city centre is a mixture of [medieval](/wiki/Medieval_architecture "Medieval architecture"), [neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture "Neoclassical architecture"), [Art Deco](/wiki/Art_Deco "Art Deco"), and [Art Nouveau](/wiki/Art_Nouveau "Art Nouveau") buildings, as well as 'neo-Romanian' buildings dating from the beginning of the 20th century and a collection of modern buildings from the 1920s and 1930s.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ The mostly utilitarian Communist-era architecture dominates most southern boroughs. Recently built contemporary structures such as skyscrapers and office buildings complete the landscape.  

### Historical architecture {#Historical_architecture}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Historical architecture")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/33%2C_Strada_Francez%C4%83%2C_Bucharest_%28Romania%29.jpg/220px-33%2C_Strada_Francez%C4%83%2C_Bucharest_%28Romania%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:33,_Strada_Francez%C4%83,_Bucharest_(Romania).jpg) [Curtea Veche Church](/wiki/Curtea_Veche_Church "Curtea Veche Church")

Of the city's [medieval](/wiki/Middle_Ages "Middle Ages") architecture, most of what survived into modern times was destroyed by communist [systematization](/wiki/Systematization_(Romania) "Systematization (Romania)"), fire, and military incursions. Some medieval and renaissance edifices remain, the most notable are in the Lipscani area. This precinct contains notable buildings such as [Manuc's Inn](/wiki/Manuc%27s_Inn "Manuc's Inn") (*Hanul lui Manuc* ) and the ruins of the [Old Court](/wiki/Curtea_Veche "Curtea Veche") (*Curtea Veche* ); during the late Middle Ages, this area was the heart of commerce in Bucharest. From the 1970s onwards, the area went through urban decline, and many historical buildings fell into disrepair. In 2005, the Lipscani area was restored.^[\[123\]](#cite_note-123)^{#cite_ref-123}

To execute a massive redevelopment project during the rule of Nicolae Ceaușescu, the government conducted extensive demolition of churches and many other historic structures in Romania. According to Alexandru Budișteanu, former chief architect of Bucharest, "The sight of a church bothered Ceaușescu. It didn't matter if they demolished or moved it, as long as it was no longer in sight". Nevertheless, a project organised by Romanian engineer Eugeniu Iordăchescu was able to move many historic structures to less-prominent sites and save them.^[\[124\]](#cite_note-124)^{#cite_ref-124}

The city centre has retained architecture from the late 19th and early 20th centuries, particularly the [interwar period](/wiki/Interwar_period "Interwar period"), which is often seen as the 'golden age' of Bucharest architecture. During this time, the city grew in size and wealth, therefore seeking to emulate other large European capitals such as Paris. Much of the architecture of the time belongs to a Modern (rationalist) Architecture current, led by Horia Creangă and [Marcel Iancu](/wiki/Marcel_Iancu "Marcel Iancu").

In Romania, the tendencies of innovation in the architectural language met the need of valorisation and affirmation of the national cultural identity. The [Art Nouveau](/wiki/Art_Nouveau "Art Nouveau") movement found expression through new architectural style initiated by [Ion Mincu](/wiki/Ion_Mincu "Ion Mincu") and taken over by other prestigious architects who capitalised important references of Romanian laic and medieval ecclesiastical architecture (for example the [Mogoșoaia Palace](/wiki/Mogo%C8%99oaia_Palace "Mogoșoaia Palace"), the [Stavropoleos Church](/wiki/Stavropoleos_Monastery "Stavropoleos Monastery") or the disappeared church of Văcărești Monastery) and Romanian folk motifs.^[\[125\]](#cite_note-125)^ The [Romanian Revival architecture](/wiki/Romanian_Revival_architecture "Romanian Revival architecture"), which was born as the result of the attempts of finding a specific Romanian architectural style, is exemplified though buildings such as [Nicolae Minovici Folk Art Museum](/wiki/Nicolae_Minovici_Folk_Art_Museum "Nicolae Minovici Folk Art Museum") and the [Romanian Peasant Museum](/wiki/Romanian_Peasant_Museum "Romanian Peasant Museum").{#cite_ref-125}

Another style of the 1930s is the Moorish-Florentine or Mediterranean Picturesque, which [eclectically](/wiki/Eclecticism_in_architecture "Eclecticism in architecture") uses [Romanesque](/wiki/Romanesque_architecture "Romanesque architecture"), [Gothic](/wiki/Gothic_architecture "Gothic architecture") and [Renaissance](/wiki/Renaissance_architecture "Renaissance architecture") elements in civic architecture, with a Mediterranean vibe, giving rise to [Mediterranean Revival architecture](/wiki/Mediterranean_Revival_architecture "Mediterranean Revival architecture").

Some buildings from the interwar era have a modernist brutalist look, such as the Tehnoimport Building, which was built in 1935,^[\[126\]](#cite_note-126)^ and may be mistaken as communist architecture. Modernist styles during the interwar period include [Art Deco](/wiki/Art_Deco "Art Deco"), [Stripped Classicism](/wiki/Stripped_Classicism "Stripped Classicism"), [Bauhaus](/wiki/Bauhaus "Bauhaus") and [Rationalism](/wiki/Rationalism "Rationalism").{#cite_ref-126}

Two buildings from this time are the [Crețulescu Palace](/wiki/Cre%C8%9Bulescu_Palace "Crețulescu Palace"), housing cultural institutions including [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO")'s European Centre for Higher Education, and the [Cotroceni Palace](/wiki/Cotroceni_Palace "Cotroceni Palace"), the residence of the [Romanian President](/wiki/President_of_Romania "President of Romania"). Many large-scale constructions such as the Gara de Nord, the busiest railway station in the city, National Bank of Romania's headquarters, and the [Telephones Company Building](/wiki/Telephones_Company_Building "Telephones Company Building") date from these times. In the 2000s, some historic buildings in the city centre underwent restoration. In some residential areas of the city, particularly in high-income central and northern districts, [turn-of-the-20th-century](/wiki/Fin-de-siecle "Fin-de-siecle") villas were mostly restored beginning in the late 1990s.

### Communist era architecture {#Communist_era_architecture}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Communist era architecture")\]

|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) | This section **does not [cite](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources") any [sources](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")** . Please help [improve this section](/wiki/Special:EditPage/Bucharest "Special:EditPage/Bucharest") by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners "Help:Referencing for beginners"). Unsourced material may be challenged and [removed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Burden_of_evidence "Wikipedia:Verifiability"). *(April 2024)**([Learn how and when to remove this message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))* |

A major part of Bucharest's architecture is made up of buildings constructed during the [Communist era](/wiki/Communist_Romania "Communist Romania") replacing the historical architecture with high-density apartment blocks -- significant portions of the [historic centre of Bucharest](/wiki/Ceau%C8%99ima "Ceaușima") were demolished to construct one of the largest buildings in the world, the [Palace of the Parliament](/wiki/Palace_of_the_Parliament "Palace of the Parliament") (then officially called the House of the Republic). In Nicolae Ceaușescu's project of systematization, new buildings were built in previously historical areas, which were razed and then built upon.

Communist architecture broadly includes three stages: architecture that was built in the early years of communism, in the late 1940s and 1950s, which followed the Soviet Stalinist trend of [Socialist Realism](/wiki/Socialist_Realism "Socialist Realism"), an example being the [House of the Free Press](/wiki/House_of_the_Free_Press "House of the Free Press") (which was named *Casa Scînteii* during communism); postwar Modernism in the 1960s and the 1970s; and the [systematization](/wiki/Systematization_(Romania) "Systematization (Romania)") program of the late 1970s and 1980s, which included mass demolitions of historical buildings and their replacement with [North Korean](/wiki/North_Korea "North Korea") influenced buildings after Nicolae Ceaușescu visited [East Asia](/wiki/East_Asia "East Asia") in 1971, and was impressed by its [Juche](/wiki/Juche "Juche") [ideology](/wiki/Ideology "Ideology").

The Communist regime installed after World War II took control over all aspects of life, including architecture, dictating a uniform bureaucratic vision of urbanism and architectural design. [Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej](/wiki/Gheorghe_Gheorghiu-Dej "Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej"), who was premier of the Socialist Republic of Romania from 1947 until 1965, began the country's policies of industrialization, with infrastructure development for heavy industry, and construction for mass resettlement to new industrial and agricultural centers away from Bucharest and other principal cities. The architecture from this period is more or less easy to spot, by its use of Neoclassical elements and proportions, but in a simplified way. There are also some small 3-4 floors "Russian blocks" from this era, some of them built of red bricks.

Communist-era architecture from the 1960s and 1970s can be found especially in Bucharest's residential districts, mainly in *blocuri*, which are high-density apartment blocks that house the majority of the city's population. Initially, these apartment blocks started to be constructed in the 1960s, on relatively empty areas and fields (good examples include Pajura, Drumul Taberei, Berceni and Titan), however with the 1970s, they mostly targeted peripheral neighbourhoods such as Colentina, Pantelimon, Militari and Rahova. Construction of these apartment blocks were also often randomised, for instance some small streets were demolished and later widened with the blocks being built next to them, but other neighbouring streets were left intact (like in the example of Calea Moșilor from 1978 to 1982), or built in various patterns such as the Piața Iancului-Lizeanu apartment buildings from 1962 to 1963.

The last years of communism were marked by major urban redevelopment schemes which changed dramatically the face of many cities, including Bucharest. One of the most singular examples of late stage communist architecture of the 1980s is [Centrul Civic](/wiki/Centrul_Civic "Centrul Civic"), a development that replaced a major part of Bucharest's historic city centre with giant utilitarian buildings, mainly with [marble](/wiki/Marble "Marble") or [travertine](/wiki/Travertine "Travertine") façades, inspired by North Korean architecture. The mass demolitions that occurred in the 1980s, under which an overall area of eight square kilometres of the historic centre of Bucharest were levelled, including monasteries, churches, synagogues, a hospital, and a noted [Art Deco](/wiki/Art_Deco "Art Deco") sports stadium, changed drastically the appearance of the city.

### Contemporary architecture {#Contemporary_architecture}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Contemporary architecture")\]

Since [the fall of communism in 1989](/wiki/Romanian_Revolution_of_1989 "Romanian Revolution of 1989"), several communist-era buildings have been refurbished, modernised, and used for other purposes.^[\[127\]](#cite_note-127)^ Perhaps the best example of this is the conversion of obsolete retail complexes into shopping malls and commercial centres. These giant, circular halls, which were unofficially called [hunger circuses](/wiki/Hunger_circus "Hunger circus") due to the food shortages experienced in the 1980s, were constructed during the Ceaușescu era to act as produce markets and [refectories](/wiki/Refectory "Refectory"), although most were left unfinished at the time of the revolution.{#cite_ref-127}

Modern shopping malls such as the [Unirea Shopping Centre](/wiki/Unirea_Shopping_Center "Unirea Shopping Center"), [Bucharest Mall](/wiki/Bucharest_Mall "Bucharest Mall"), [Plaza Romania](/wiki/Plaza_Romania "Plaza Romania"), and [City Mall](/wiki/City_Mall,_Romania "City Mall, Romania") emerged on pre-existent structures of former hunger circuses. Another example is the conversion of a large utilitarian construction in Centrul Civic into a [Marriott Hotel](/wiki/Marriott_International "Marriott International"). This process was accelerated after 2000, when the city underwent a property boom, and many communist-era buildings in the city centre became prime real estate due to their location. Many communist-era apartment blocks have also been refurbished to improve urban appearance.

The newest contribution to Bucharest's architecture took place after the fall of communism, particularly after 2000, when the city went through a period of urban renewal -- and architectural revitalization -- on the back of Romania's economic growth. Buildings from this time are mostly made of glass and steel, and often have more than 10 stories. Examples include shopping malls (particularly the Bucharest Mall, a conversion and extension of an abandoned building), office buildings, bank headquarters, etc.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

During the 21st century, several high rise office buildings were built, particularly in the northern and eastern parts of the city. Additionally, a trend to add modern wings and façades to historic buildings has occurred, the most prominent example of which is the Bucharest Architects' Association Building, which is a modern glass-and-steel construction built inside a historic stone façade. In 2013, the Bucharest skyline enriched with a 137-m-high office building (SkyTower of [Floreasca City Centre](/wiki/Floreasca_City_Center "Floreasca City Center")), the tallest building in Romania. Examples of modern skyscrapers built in the 21st century include [Bucharest Tower Centre](/wiki/Bucharest_Tower_Center "Bucharest Tower Center"), [Euro Tower](/wiki/Euro_Tower_(Bucharest) "Euro Tower (Bucharest)"), [Nusco Tower](/wiki/Nusco_Tower "Nusco Tower"), [Cathedral Plaza](/wiki/Cathedral_Plaza "Cathedral Plaza"), [City Gate Towers](/wiki/City_Gate_Towers "City Gate Towers"), [Rin Grand Hotel](/wiki/Rin_Grand_Hotel "Rin Grand Hotel"), [Premium Plaza](/wiki/Premium_Plaza "Premium Plaza"), [Bucharest Corporate Centre](/wiki/Bucharest_Corporate_Center "Bucharest Corporate Center"), [Millennium Business Centre](/wiki/Millennium_Business_Center "Millennium Business Center"), [PGV Tower](/wiki/Phoenix_Tower,_Bucharest "Phoenix Tower, Bucharest"), [Charles de Gaulle Plaza](/wiki/Charles_de_Gaulle_Plaza "Charles de Gaulle Plaza"), Business Development Centre Bucharest, [BRD Tower](/wiki/BRD_Tower_Bucharest "BRD Tower Bucharest"), and [Bucharest Financial Plaza](/wiki/Bucharest_Financial_Plaza "Bucharest Financial Plaza"). Despite this vertical development, Romanian architects avoid designing very tall buildings due to vulnerability to earthquakes.^[\[128\]](#cite_note-128)^{#cite_ref-128}

Aside from buildings used for business and institutions, residential developments have also been built, many of which consist of high-rise office buildings and suburban residential communities. An example of a new high rise residential complex is [Asmita Gardens](/wiki/Asmita_Gardens "Asmita Gardens"). These developments are increasingly prominent in northern Bucharest, which is less densely populated and is home to middle- and upper-class Bucharesters due to the process of [gentrification](/wiki/Gentrification "Gentrification").

Education {#Education}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Education")\]

Overall, 159 faculties are in 34 universities. Sixteen public universities are in Bucharest, the largest of which are the [University of Bucharest](/wiki/University_of_Bucharest "University of Bucharest"), the [Politehnica University of Bucharest](/wiki/Politehnica_University_of_Bucharest "Politehnica University of Bucharest"), the [Bucharest University of Economic Studies](/wiki/Bucharest_University_of_Economic_Studies "Bucharest University of Economic Studies"), the [Carol Davila University of Medicine and Pharmacy](/wiki/Carol_Davila_University_of_Medicine_and_Pharmacy "Carol Davila University of Medicine and Pharmacy"), [Technical University of Civil Engineering](/wiki/Technical_University_of_Civil_Engineering_of_Bucharest "Technical University of Civil Engineering of Bucharest"), the [National University of Political Studies and Public Administration](/wiki/National_University_of_Political_Studies_and_Public_Administration "National University of Political Studies and Public Administration"), and the [University of Agronomic Sciences and Veterinary Medicine of Bucharest](/wiki/University_of_Agronomic_Sciences_and_Veterinary_Medicine_of_Bucharest "University of Agronomic Sciences and Veterinary Medicine of Bucharest").

These are supplemented by nineteen private universities, such as the [Romanian-American University](/wiki/Romanian-American_University "Romanian-American University").^[\[129\]](#cite_note-129)^ Private universities, however, have a mixed reputation due to irregularities.^[\[130\]](#cite_note-130)^^[\[131\]](#cite_note-131)^{#cite_ref-131}

In the 2020 [QS World University Rankings](/wiki/QS_World_University_Rankings "QS World University Rankings"), from Bucharest, only the [University of Bucharest](/wiki/University_of_Bucharest "University of Bucharest") was included in the top universities of the world. The [Politehnica University](/wiki/Politehnica_University_of_Bucharest "Politehnica University of Bucharest") disappeared from the ranking.^[\[132\]](#cite_note-132)^ Also, in recent years, the city has had increasing numbers of foreign students enrolling in its universities.^[\[133\]](#cite_note-133)^{#cite_ref-133}

The first modern educational institution was the [Princely Academy from Bucharest](/wiki/Princely_Academy_of_Bucharest "Princely Academy of Bucharest"), founded in 1694 and divided in 1864 to form the present-day University of Bucharest and the [Saint Sava National College](/wiki/Saint_Sava_National_College "Saint Sava National College"), both of which are among the most prestigious of their kind in Romania.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-134)^^[\[135\]](#cite_note-135)^{#cite_ref-135}

Over 450 public primary and secondary schools are in the city, all of which are administered by the Bucharest Municipal Schooling Inspectorate. Each [sector](/wiki/Sectors_of_Bucharest "Sectors of Bucharest") also has its own Schooling Inspectorate, subordinated to the municipal one.

Media {#Media}
--------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: Media")\]

The city is well-served by a modern landline and mobile network. Offices of [Poșta Română](/wiki/Po%C8%99ta_Rom%C3%A2n%C4%83 "Poșta Română"), the national postal operator, are spread throughout the city, with the central post office ([Romanian](/wiki/Romanian_language "Romanian language"): *Oficiul Poștal București 1* ) located at 12 Matei Millo Street. [Public telephones](/wiki/Payphone "Payphone") are located in many places and are operated by [Telekom Romania](/wiki/Telekom_Romania "Telekom Romania"), a subsidiary of [Deutsche Telekom](/wiki/Deutsche_Telekom "Deutsche Telekom") and successor of the former monopoly [Romtelecom](/wiki/Romtelecom "Romtelecom").

Bucharest is the headquarters of most national television networks and national newspapers, radio stations and online news websites. The largest daily newspapers in Bucharest include *[Evenimentul Zilei](/wiki/Evenimentul_Zilei "Evenimentul Zilei")* , *[Jurnalul Național](/wiki/Jurnalul_Na%C8%9Bional "Jurnalul Național")* , *[Cotidianul](/wiki/Cotidianul "Cotidianul")* , *[România Liberă](/wiki/Rom%C3%A2nia_Liber%C4%83 "România Liberă")* , and *[Adevărul](/wiki/Adev%C4%83rul "Adevărul")*, while the biggest news websites are [HotNews](/wiki/HotNews "HotNews") (with English and Spanish versions), [Ziare.com](https://ro.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ziare.com "ro:Ziare.com"), and *[Gândul](/wiki/G%C3%A2ndul "Gândul")* . During the rush hours, [tabloid](/wiki/Tabloid_(newspaper_format) "Tabloid (newspaper format)") newspapers *[Click!](/wiki/Click! "Click!")* , *[Libertatea](/wiki/Libertatea "Libertatea")* , and *Cancan* are popular for commuters.

Several newspapers and media publications are based in [House of the Free Press](/wiki/House_of_the_Free_Press "House of the Free Press") (*Casa Presei Libere*), a landmark of northern Bucharest, originally named Casa Scânteii after the [Communist Romania](/wiki/Communist_Romania "Communist Romania")-era official newspaper *[Scînteia](/wiki/Sc%C3%AEnteia "Scînteia")* . The House of the Free Press is not the only Bucharest landmark that grew out of the media and communications industry. [Palatul Telefoanelor](/wiki/Palatul_Telefoanelor "Palatul Telefoanelor") ("The Telephone Palace") was the first major modernist building on Calea Victoriei in the city's centre, and the massive, unfinished communist-era [Casa Radio](/wiki/Casa_Radio "Casa Radio") looms over a park a block away from the Opera.

English-language newspapers became available in the early 1930s and reappeared in the 1990s. The two daily English-language newspapers are the *[Bucharest Daily News](/wiki/Bucharest_Daily_News "Bucharest Daily News")* and *[Nine O' Clock](/wiki/Nine_O%27_Clock "Nine O' Clock")* ; several magazines and publications in other languages are available, such as the Hungarian-language daily *[Új Magyar Szó](/wiki/%C3%9Aj_Magyar_Sz%C3%B3 "Új Magyar Szó")*.

*[Observator Cultural](/wiki/Observator_Cultural "Observator Cultural")* covers the city's arts, and the free weekly magazines *[Șapte Seri](/wiki/%C8%98apte_Seri "Șapte Seri")* ("Seven Evenings") and *B24FUN* , list entertainment events. The city is home to the intellectual journal *[Dilema veche](/wiki/Dilema_veche "Dilema veche")* and the satire magazine *[Academia Cațavencu](/wiki/Academia_Ca%C8%9Bavencu "Academia Cațavencu")*.

[Visit Bucharest Today](https://visitbucharest.today/) is another online platform promoting Bucharest as a tourist destination. It serves as a comprehensive resource for local and international travelers seeking to learn about the capital city of Romania. The online platform showcases [Bucharest's rich history](/wiki/History_of_Bucharest "History of Bucharest"), cultural landmarks, hidden gems, and exciting experiences.  

Healthcare {#Healthcare}
------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: Healthcare")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Bucuresti%2C_Romania._SPITALUL_COLTEA_%28B-II-m-A-18220.02%29.jpg/220px-Bucuresti%2C_Romania._SPITALUL_COLTEA_%28B-II-m-A-18220.02%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bucuresti,_Romania._SPITALUL_COLTEA_(B-II-m-A-18220.02).jpg) Colțea Hospital in 2018

One of the most modern hospitals in the capital is Colțea that has been re-equipped after a 90-million-euro investment in 2011. It specialises in oncological and cardiac disorders. It was built by Mihai Cantacuzino between 1701 and 1703, composed of many buildings, each with 12 to 30 beds, a church, three chapels, a school, and doctors' and teachers' houses.^[\[136\]](#cite_note-136)^{#cite_ref-136}

Another conventional hospital is Pantelimon, which was established in 1733 by [Grigore II Ghica](/wiki/Grigore_II_Ghica "Grigore II Ghica"). The surface area of the hospital land property was 400,000 m^2^ (4,305,564 sq ft). The hospital had in its inventory a house for infectious diseases and a house for persons with disabilities.

Other hospitals or clinics are [Bucharest Emergency Hospital](/wiki/Bucharest_Emergency_Hospital "Bucharest Emergency Hospital"), [Floreasca Emergency Clinic Hospital](/wiki/Floreasca_Hospital "Floreasca Hospital"), Bucharest University Emergency Hospital, and Fundeni Clinical Institute or Biomedica International and Euroclinic, which are private.  

Sports {#Sports}
----------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Sports")\]

[Football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football") is the most widely followed sport in Bucharest, with the city having numerous club teams, including, most notably, [Steaua București](/wiki/CSA_Steaua_Bucure%C8%99ti_(football) "CSA Steaua București (football)"), [Dinamo București](/wiki/FC_Dinamo_Bucure%C8%99ti "FC Dinamo București"), [Rapid București](/wiki/FC_Rapid_Bucure%C8%99ti "FC Rapid București") and [FCSB](/wiki/FCSB "FCSB").

[Arena Națională](/wiki/Arena_Na%C8%9Bional%C4%83 "Arena Națională"), a new stadium inaugurated on 6 September 2011, hosted the [2012 Europa League Final](/wiki/2012_UEFA_Europa_League_Final "2012 UEFA Europa League Final")^[\[137\]](#cite_note-137)^ and has a 55,600-seat capacity, making it one of the largest stadiums in Southeastern Europe and one of the few with a roof.^[\[138\]](#cite_note-138)^{#cite_ref-138}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Arena-bukareszt.jpg/220px-Arena-bukareszt.jpg)](/wiki/File:Arena-bukareszt.jpg) [Arena Națională](/wiki/Arena_Na%C8%9Bional%C4%83 "Arena Națională") hosted the [2012 UEFA Europa League final](/wiki/2012_UEFA_Europa_League_final "2012 UEFA Europa League final") and [UEFA Euro 2020](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2020 "UEFA Euro 2020") matches.

Sport clubs have formed for [handball](/wiki/Team_handball "Team handball"), [water polo](/wiki/Water_polo "Water polo"), [volleyball](/wiki/Volleyball "Volleyball"), [rugby union](/wiki/Rugby_union "Rugby union"), [basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball") and [ice hockey](/wiki/Ice_hockey "Ice hockey"). The majority of Romanian [track and field](/wiki/Track_and_field "Track and field") athletes and most [gymnasts](/wiki/Artistic_gymnastics "Artistic gymnastics") are affiliated with clubs in Bucharest. The largest indoor arena in Bucharest is the [Romexpo](/wiki/Romexpo "Romexpo") Dome with a seating capacity of 40,000. It can be used for boxing, kickboxing, handball and tennis.

Bucharest hosted annual races along a temporary urban track surrounding the Palace of the Parliament, called [Bucharest Ring](/wiki/Bucharest_Ring "Bucharest Ring"). The [Bucharest City Challenge](/wiki/2008_FIA_GT_Bucharest_2_Hours "2008 FIA GT Bucharest 2 Hours") race hosted [FIA GT](/wiki/FIA_GT "FIA GT"), [FIA GT3](/wiki/FIA_GT3 "FIA GT3"), [British F3](/wiki/British_F3 "British F3"), and [Logan Cup](/wiki/Dacia_Logan "Dacia Logan") races.^[\[139\]](#cite_note-139)^ Since 2009, Bucharest has the largest [Ferrari](/wiki/Ferrari "Ferrari") Shop in Eastern Europe and the 2nd largest in Europe after Milan shop.^[\[140\]](#cite_note-140)^^[\[141\]](#cite_note-141)^{#cite_ref-141}

The capital also hosted the international tennis tournaments [WTA Bucharest Open](/wiki/Bucharest_Open "Bucharest Open") and [ATP Romanian Open](/wiki/Romanian_Open "Romanian Open"). Ice hockey games are held at the [Mihai Flamaropol Arena](/wiki/Patinoarul_Mihai_Flamaropol "Patinoarul Mihai Flamaropol"), which holds 8,000 spectators. Rugby games are held in different locations, but the most modern stadium is [Arcul de Triumf Stadium](/wiki/Stadionul_Arcul_de_Triumf "Stadionul Arcul de Triumf"), which is also home to the [Romanian national rugby team](/wiki/Romania_national_rugby_union_team "Romania national rugby union team").

Bucharest hosted the [UEFA Euro 2020](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2020 "UEFA Euro 2020") championship at the [Arena Națională](/wiki/Arena_Na%C8%9Bional%C4%83 "Arena Națională") or Bucharest National Arena.^[\[142\]](#cite_note-142)^ The championship took place in 2021, being postponed due to the outbreak of the [COVID-19 pandemic](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic "COVID-19 pandemic").{#cite_ref-142}  

Twin towns -- sister cities {#Twin_towns_.E2.80.93_sister_cities}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bucharest&action=edit&section=37 "Edit section: Twin towns – sister cities")\]
